question.text: Trees or shrubs
Climbers
Leaves spirally arranged
Leaves opposite or in whorls
Gynoecium 2-carpellate, apocarpous but apically united into a common style; corolla tube 8-43 mm long; fruit of paired single-seeded drupes, sometimes only one developing
Gynoecium 3-5-carpellate, apocarpous but apically united into a common style, or syncarpous; corolla tube 6.5-16 mm long; fruit a distinctive basket-like structure or a solitary 1-5-seeded drupe
Gynoecium apocarpous but apically united into a common style; fruit a distinctive basket-like structure
Gynoecium syncarpous; fruit not forming a basket-like structure
Leaves in whorls, sometimes with some opposite pairs but never exclusively so
Leaves exclusively opposite
Large unbuttressed trees; branchlets strongly ribbed; corolla tube much shorter than lobes; fruit a follicle with winged seeds
Shrubs to large trees, with or without buttresses or fluted trunks; branchlets not or only weakly ribbed; corolla tube longer than lobes; fruit a drupe or a follicle with ciliate or arillate seeds
Small intrapetiolar stipule-like structures present in the axils of the petiole with the stem; fruit of follicles with arillate seeds
Small intrapetiolar stipule-like structures absent in the axils of the petiole with the stem; fruit a drupe or a follicle with ciliate seeds
Corolla lobes dextrorse; fruit of paired follicles or of drupes with a stony or fibrous mesocarp
Corolla lobes sinistrorse; fruit of paired or single follicles or of drupes with a fairly thin mesocarp
Disk absent or of two lobes; fruit of paired or syncarpous indehiscent drupes
Disk a small annular thickening at base of ovaries; fruit of paired dehiscent follicles
Disk absent; fruit of paired drupes with a thin endocarp, often in moniliform chains; seeds ruminate
Disk present (but often small); fruit of paired or syncarpous non-moniliform drupes with a hard pericarp or paired or syncarpous follicles
Style head with a basal collar; fruit of paired or syncarpous indehiscent drupes
Style head without a basal collar; fruit of paired or solitary dehiscent follicles
Shrubs or small trees armed with thorns
Shrubs to large trees without thorns
Small intrapetiolar stipule-like structures present; corolla lobes sinistrorse; stamens free from the style head; fruit with arillate seeds
Small intrapetiolar stipule-like structures absent; flower and fruit characters variable
Stamens coherent with style head; calyx lobes free or connate into a tube for at least half their length
Stamens not coherent with style head; calyx lobes not connate or only connate at base and not forming a tube
Leaves with domatia on the undersurface
Leaves without domatia on the undersurface
Corolla lobes sinistrorse
Corolla lobes dextrorse
Stamens not adnate to the pistil; corolla without a corona, fruit a berry or drupe
Stamens adnate to the pistil; corolla with or without a corona; fruit a follicle
Calyx not connate into a tube; stamens not sagittate at base; fruit of paired drupes or paired berries
Calyx often connate into a tube or lobes free; stamens sagittate at base; fruit with arillate seeds
Shrub; disk present; fruit of paired drupes (rare forms of Rauvolfia with opposite leaves)
Shrub or tree; disk absent; fruit of paired berries
Shrubs; corolla infundibuliform, widening around the middle; fruit of paired follicles held erect
Trees or shrubs; corolla salverform; fruit of paired or solitary drupes or of paired pendulous or erect follicles
Flowers in fascicles; stamens clearly adnate to the style head; fruit of paired follicles
Flowers not in fascicles; stamens apparently free from the style head; fruit of paired follicles, berries or drupes or of syncarpous drupes
Corolla completely puberulent outside; fruit of paired follicles; seeds with a coma
Corolla glabrous or only sparsely puberulent around the top outside; fruit of paired or syncarpous drupes; seeds without a coma
Disk > 0.5 times height of ovaries; corolla tube 7-45 mm long; fruit of thin-walled drupes, often with a spur on one side
Disk, if present, < 0.5 times height of ovaries; corolla tube 3-14.3 mm long; fruit of thick-walled fibrous or stony drupes without a spur on one side
Climbing with tendrils; gynoecium syncarpous; fruit a berry
Climbing without tendrils; gynoecium syncarpous or apocarpous but united into a single style; fruit various
Leaves in whorls of 3 or more
Leaves strictly opposite
Stamens adnate to the style head; fruit a follicle; seeds with a coma
Stamens free from the style head; fruit of paired drupes, often in moniliform chains; seeds without a coma
Corolla lobes sinistrorse; fruit of paired or solitary berries, drupes, or follicles
Corolla lobes dextrorse or valvate in bud; fruit of paired or solitary follicles
Stamens adnate to the style head; fruit of paired torulose follicles; seeds with a coma
Stamens free from the style head; fruit of paired or solitary drupes, a berry, or a berry-like fleshy fruit that later dehisces; seeds without a coma
Flowers 4-merous; fruit a berry
Flowers 5-merous; fruit various
Corolla with a corona in the throat; fruit a hard walled berry
Corolla without a corona; fruit berry-like and fleshy but later dehiscing, or of paired, often moniliform, drupes
Leaves punctate beneath, bases with small intrapetiolar ocrea; gynoecium syncarpous, unilocular; fruit berry-like, various shapes, fleshy but later dehiscing; seeds with a corky aril

Leaves punctate or not beneath, bases without small intrapetiolar ocrea; gynoecium apocarpus but apically united into a single style; fruit drupaceous, moniliform (or reduced to one part), indehiscent; seeds without an aril
Calyx fused into a tube, 5-dentate around edge
Calyx of 5 free sepals
Corolla with a narrow basal tube and then opening up into a wide open upper tube; stamens with a bulbous growth facing outwards
Corolla various; stamens without a bulbous growth
Style distinctly swollen in the middle; stamens strongly exserted from corolla tube
Style not distinctly swollen in the middle; stamens exserted or included in corolla tube
Corolla with a corona at the throat (often quite small — observe carefully)
Corolla without a corona at the throat
Anthers with an elongated acumen; corolla lobes drawn out into long tails or not; seeds without an apical coma-bearing beak
Anthers without an elongated acumen; corolla lobes not drawn out into long tails; seeds with an apical coma-bearing beak
Stamens partially or completely exserted from corolla tube
Stamens completely included within the corolla tube
Corolla infundibuliform with a large open upper tube; corolla tube ≥ 2 cm long
Corolla salverform, upper part of tube not large and open; corolla tube < 1.5 cm long
Only tips of anthers exserted from corolla throat; gynoecium apocarpous but with an apically united style; fruit of paired follicles
Anthers completely or mostly exserted from corolla throat; gynoecium syncarpous; fruit of bilocular solitary follicles
Inflorescence ≥ 3 cm long; corolla inside pubescent around the top of tube or glabrous
Inflorescence < 3 cm long; corolla inside pubescent near base
Corolla tube ≥ 18 mm long
Corolla tube < 18 mm long
Corolla infundibuliform with a large open upper tube; filaments > 1 cm long
Corolla salverform, upper part of the tube not large and open; filaments < 1 cm long
Stamens only weakly attached to the style head; secondary veins on leaf blades quite straight and forming a stong intramarginal vein
Stamens firmly attached to the style head; secondary veins on leaf blades arcuate ascending, if forming an intramarginal vein this strongly looped and weak
Inflorescence umbelliform; sepals ≤ 5 mm long; corolla lobes < 20 mm long
Inflorescence not umbelliform; sepals > 5 mm long; corolla lobes > 20 mm long
Leaf blades with domatia in the axils of the secondary veins and midrib beneath (check several leaves)
Leaf blades without domatia beneath (check several leaves)
Colleters many in a row on the inside of the sepals; corolla lobes dextrorse; seeds linear, glabrous
Colleters few or absent on the inside of the sepals; corolla lobes dextrorse or valvate in bud; seeds elliptic, densely pubescent
Inflorescence umbelliform; corolla tube much longer than lobes
Inflorescence various but not umbelliform; corolla tube shorter or longer than lobes
Gynoecium pubescent
Gynoecium glabrous
Gynoecium syncarpous; stamens filaments at first curving downwards and then upwards; corolla urceolate. — Moluccas
Gynoecium apocarpous but uniting into a single style; stamens not as above; corolla various. — Throughout Malesia
Leaves with a very well developed intramarginal vein
Leaves without a well developed intramarginal vein, sometimes weakly developed and strongly looped (if in doubt take this lead)
Corolla tube > 8 mm long; corolla lobes > 8 mm long
Corolla tube < 8 mm long; corolla lobes < 8 mm long
Stamens inserted at base of corolla tube; corolla urceolate or campanulate; seed grain pubescent
Stamens inserted around middle of corolla tube; corolla salverform; seed grain glabrous
Disk lobes free and narrow, never shorter than the ovaries; anthers appearing elliptic; secondary veins 4-8 pairs
Disk entire and 5-dentate or of 5 wide lobes, mostly shorter than the ovaries; anthers narrowly triangular; secondary veins 5-21 pairs
Disk of 2 lobes alternating between the ovaries; stamens only weakly attached to the style head. — Philippines (maybe also in New Guinea)
Disk a 5-lobed ring or of 5 separate lobes; stamens firmly attached to the style head. — Throughout Malesia
Disk of 5 separate lobes
Disk in a 5-crenate or 5-dentate ring
Corolla lobes > 2 times as long as wide, usually slightly inrolled at margins; anthers pubescent externally
Corolla lobes < 2 times as long as wide, not inrolled at margins; anthers glabrous externally
Leaves with an intramarginal vein that is as strong as the secondary veins and prominent beneath; seeds with the coma arising more or less from a single point
Leaves without a strong intramarginal vein; seeds with a long beak along which the coma arises

key.keyTitle: KEY TO EXOTIC COMMONLY CULTIVATED SPECIES
key.keynotes: Only genera which are not at all native to Malesia are included here. Native genera with non-native cultivated species (e.g. Carissa, Kopsia, Tabernaemontana, Wrightia) and some native species which also happen to be cultivated (e.g. Cerbera odollam) are included in the main body of the treatment. If the key to commonly cultivated species does not yield any results then the main keys should be used. It is possible, even probable, that many more exotic species are occasionally cultivated in Malesia but this key deals only with the commonly encountered exotic species found throughout the region.

question.text: Herbs, sometimes with a woody base
Trees or shrubs or climbers
Leaves spirally arranged
Leaves opposite or in whorls
Leaves narrowly oblong, < 1 cm wide
Leaves obovate or elliptic, > 2 cm wide
Succulent shrub; corolla tube wide; anthers with long bristly appendages
Small trees; corolla tube narrow; anthers without long bristly appendages
Leaf blade rounded at apex, dark green, shiny above
Leaf blade acute or acuminate at apex, glaucous, dull above
Corolla tube not yellow, < 3 cm long; anthers with long appendages
Corolla tube yellow, infundibuliform, > 3.5 cm long, anthers without appendages
Sepals without colleters inside; lower, narrow corolla tube about equal in length to upper, wider corolla tube
Sepals with colleters inside; lower, narrow corolla tube much shorter than upper, wider corolla tube

feature.char: Large or medium woody climbers.
Leaves opposite; usually with an interpetiolar ridge bearing colleters.
Inflorescence terminal, sometimes also axillary, cymose, often forming a panicle; flowers 5-merous.
Sepals narrowly ovate to linear, quite large and showy; colleters in sepal sinuses inside.
Corolla lobes dextrorse in bud; mature corolla with spreading or erect lobes.
Disk a continuous ring, flat-topped or 5-lobed.
Fruit of paired follicles; linear.
Seeds flattened, narrowly ellipsoid, glabrous; with an apical coma.

feature.string: Distribution 7 species from India and southern China to western Malesia (1 species).
NoteThe genus Amphineurion is here treated as distinct from Aganosma. Amphineurion includes the common Amphineurion marginatum, formerly Aganosma marginata.

feature.char: Stems lenticellate or not; stems strigose or tomentose, often becoming glabrous.
Inflorescence robust and lax, 4.6-19.5 cm long, strigose or tomentose; pedicels 6-17 mm long.
Sepals 9-23 by 1.8-6.1 mm, 3.2-10 times as long as wide, narrowly ovate, tomentose; colleters few in sinuses or frequently absent.
Stamens inserted at 2.3-4.5 mm from corolla base which is 0.2-0.4 of tube length; anthers 4.7-7.5 by 1-1.6 mm, 3.3-6.1 times as long as wide.
Disk narrower at top, 5-dentate; 1.1-3 mm long, 1.1-3.8 times as long as ovary.
Fruit unknown.

feature.string: Distribution Burma, Thailand; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Java.
Habitat & EcologyIn evergreen forest to 400 m.
UsesRecorded as being used to treat diseases of the bile and blood.

feature.char: Shrubs or trees.
Branches smooth to slightly rough, lenticellate or not; puberulous or pubescent.
Leaves in whorls (in Malesia); petiolate or sessile, colleter(s) present in the axils.
Inflorescence compound, cymose, terminal, pedunculate, frequently in whorls or umbellate, few- to many-flowered.
Flowers 5-merous, actinomorphic, mostly fragrant.
Sepals without colleters in the axils.
Disk a thickening at the base, or 2-lobed and alternating with the carpels (sect. Blaberopus — not in Malesia).
Fruit a pair of follicles (a single 2-celled follicle only in A. rostrata).
Seeds numerous, elliptic, narrowly elliptic or oblong, ends rounded to acuminate, or caudate, glabrous or pubescent, long cilia forming a coma of simple hairs.

feature.string: Distribution The genus has 43 species, ranging from tropical Africa to Central America, and from the Himalayas and China to New South Wales, Australia. However, it is likely that the Central American species should be removed from Alstonia, and the genus Tonduzia resurrected, as molecular work shows them not to be at all closely related (Endress, pers. comm.). In Malesia 16 species in two sections, sect. Alstonia and sect. Monuraspermum. Map 2.
Habitat & EcologySecondary and primary forests, in swamps or dry habitats, on various soils: sandy, clay, or limestone.Altitude 0-2870 m .

Colleters minute or shortly lingulate or narrow, 0.1-0.15 wide; corolla lobes dextrorse; seeds acuminate at one end; leaves in whorls of 3 or 4; without white latex from the trunk bark of the tree

question.text: Trunk with copious white latex from the inner bark; colleter(s) in the leaf-axils deltoid and usually more or less as wide as the leaf-scars, or narrowly triangular, 0.3-0.7 mm wide; corolla lobes sinistrorse; seeds rounded at both ends; leaves in whorls of (3-)4-9

Trunk without white latex from the inner bark; colleters in the leaf-axils minute or narrowly lingulate, 0.1-0.15 mm wide; corolla lobes dextrorse; seeds acuminate or caudate; leaves consistently in whorls of 3 or 4
Branches or branchlets usually with a distinctly shorter internode at the end; leaves long-acuminate; ovary syncarpous; follicles solitary
Branches or branchlets without a distinctly shorter internode at the end; leaf apex retuse to shortly acuminate; ovary apocarpous; follicles in pairs

Leaves with the tertiary venation more or less conspicuous above; petiole with a distinct narrow intrapetiolar stipule at the base; colleters narrowly triangular; corolla (sometimes partly) pubescent outside
Leaves with the tertiary venation mostly inconspicuous or obscure above; petioles without intrapetiolar stipule at the base; colleters deltoid; corolla glabrous outside
Leaves elliptic or narrowly so, rarely slightly obovate, apex usually obtuse or shortly acuminate
Leaves strongly obovate or spathulate, apex rounded or retuse
Sepals pubescent outside; leaves 1.5-7 cm wide. — Thailand, Western Malesia
Sepals glabrous outside; leaves 0.7-2.2 cm wide. — Papua New Guinea, Australia
Flowers very densely clustered, usually forming two clusters; corolla tube 1.8-2.8 times as long as the lobes which are 2.6-4 mm long; follicles glabrous
Flowers rather lax; corolla tube 1-1.7 times as long as the lobes which are 4-6.5 mm long; follicles pubescent
Leaves usually sessile, rarely petiolate; flowers many and densely clustered, usually into two clusters; sepals pubescent outside; corolla lobes 3-4.3(-5) by 2-3.2 mm; follicles pubescent
Leaves petiolate; inflorescences few-flowered, lax; sepals glabrous outside; corolla lobes 6.7-11 by 3.5-6 mm, follicles glabrous
Sepals grey- or rusty-pubescent outside
Sepals glabrous or laxly puberulous outside
Corolla glabrous or very sparsely hairy outside (usually around the apex), dark brown or blackish when dried
Corolla pubescent outside, sometimes puberulous only around the apex, usually pale or rusty brown due to the hairs
Leaves glabrous on both sides, secondary veins 12-17 pairs; sepals pubescent (except on the fused part) inside
Leaves glabrous or sparsely hairy above, densely velutinous beneath, secondary veins 23-26 pairs; sepals glabrous inside
Sepals 2.5-3.7 mm long, usually ovate; corolla tube 3.8 mm long; corolla lobes 3.5-5.8 mm long, ciliate or not. — Philippines
Sepals c. 1.7 mm long, turbinate; corolla tube c. 2 mm long; corolla lobes c. 2 mm long, ciliate. — Waigeo Island, Papua
Corolla lobes suborbicular, ovate, or sometimes shortly lingulate, 1-2.1 times as long as wide, apex rounded or obtuse
Corolla lobes narrowly ovate, rarely ovate, more than (2.6-)3.1 times as long as wide, apex acute or obtuse
Sepals pubescent inside on the lobed part. — Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Borneo
Sepals glabrous or laxly puberulous only around the apex inside. — Java, Sulawesi, Philippines to Australia and Solomon Islands
Sepals with a thick margin, usually reflexed, obovate, connate at the base at least 0.5 of the length; corolla tube 3-4.5 mm long; corolla lobes 1-2.3 by 1-1.8 mm; seeds 1.2-1.6 mm wide
Sepals with a thin margin, not reflexed, ovate, connate at the base less than 0.5 of the length; corolla tube 5.4-5.6 mm long; corolla lobes 3-4.5 by 1.8-2.3 mm; seeds 1.8-2 mm wide
Corolla tube 2-3 times as long as the lobes which are ovate or subtriangular, 1-1.3 times as long as wide, not ciliate; seeds 7-9 by 3-3.3 mm; leaves thickly coriaceous, usually abruptly acuminate
Corolla tube 0.7-1.5 times as long as the lobes which are ovate, narrowly ovate or oblong, 2.2-5 times as long as wide, ciliate or not; seeds 5-12 by 1.6-2.5 mm; leaves chartaceous or coriaceous

feature.char: Tree 25-40 m high, 35-60 cm dbh.
Bark deeply longitudinally and horizontally fissured and peeling off in rectangular flakes, greyish; inner bark soft, granular, pale yellow, with copious white latex.
Branchlets terete, glabrous.
Inflorescences 3-10(-18) cm long, 1-4 together, many-flowered; pedicels (1-)2-4(-5) mm long, slender, glabrous, usually with 1 or 2 bracteoles.
Bracts and bracteoles sepal-like, ovate or triangular, 0.5-0.7(-1) mm long, ciliate or not, glabrous on both sides, acute or obtuse.
Flowers fragrant.
Sepals light green or pale yellow, connate at the base for 0.2-0.3 mm, ovate, (0.8-)1-1.5 by 0.7-1 mm, erect, obtuse, glabrous on both sides, ciliate.
Stamens inserted at 5.2-6.4 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 1-1.2 by 0.4-0.5 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 8-20 cm by 2-2.5 mm, glabrous.
Seeds oblong, 4-5 by 1.1-1.3 mm, glabrous on both surfaces, ends rounded, longest cilia 8-10 mm long, reduced and becoming short or glabrous towards the margins.

feature.char: Tree 5-35(-46) m high, 8-70 cm dbh, fluted at base, or with small or steep buttresses.

Branchlets glabrous or puberulent.
Inflorescence 3-9 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels 0.5-2(-3) mm long, pubescent.

Stamens inserted at 2-2.8 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.7-1 by 0.3-0.4 mm, obtuse or sometimes acute.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 20-53 cm by 1.7-2.6(-3) mm, glabrous.

feature.char: Tree up to 40 m high, up to 60(-100) cm dbh, fluted at base and forming tall buttresses up to 8 m high.

Stamens inserted at 4.2-5.8 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.8-1 by 0.35-0.4 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, (15-)20-35 cm by 1.6-2.3 mm, brownish tomentose.

feature.string: Distribution Thailand; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Java.

feature.char: Small tree 5 m high, 3 cm dbh.

Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate to broadly ovate or triangular 0.4-0.9 mm long, obtuse or acute, ciliate, softly pubescent outside, glabrous inside.
Flowers: Sepals connate at the base for 0.75 mm, turbinate, c. 1.7 by 1 mm, apex rounded, ciliate, softly pubescent except at the fused part inside, erect, glaucous when dried.
Stamens inserted at c. 1.3 mm from the base; anthers ovate, c. 0.7 by 0.3 mm, acute.
Fruit unknown.

feature.char: Tree 17-28 m high, 30-60 cm dbh, without buttresses.

Bark scaly or both shallowly longitudinally and horizontally fissured (sometimes corky areas present), grey; inner bark cream, straw, or pink-brown with scattered dark fibres, paler towards cambium, without white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 4-5 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels rather stout, 1-3 mm long, puberulous or pubescent.

Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate to narrowly ovate, triangular, or sometimes uncertainly shaped, 0.6-2 mm long, obtuse, acute, acuminate or irregularly lobed at the apex, ciliate, puberulous outside, glabrous inside.
Flowers: Sepals connate at the base for c. 0.9 mm, ovate, 2.2-2.6 by 1.2-2 mm, apex obtuse or rounded, ciliate, glabrous or minutely hairy at the base outside, glabrous inside, erect.
Stamens inserted at 3.1-3.8 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 1.1-1.3 by 0.4-0.6 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 20-45 cm by 4-5 mm, glabrous.

Seeds dark brown, elliptic, 7-9 by 3-3.3 mm, pubescent on both sides, one end acuminate with an acumen 1-2.6 mm long, the other end rounded (sometimes obtuse); longest cilia 5-7 mm long, becoming gradually shorter towards the side margins.

feature.char: Tree 15-45(-70?) m high, 20-80 cm dbh, fluted at base and forming tall buttresses up to 6 m high, spreading at the base up to 2 m away from the trunk.
Bark smooth to slightly rough, scaly or both longitudinally and horizontally fissured, greyish, yellowish or dark brown; inner bark yellow or pale yellow, with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 2.5-10 mm long, usually forming of two bunches of dense and many clustered flowers; pedicels 0-1 mm long, pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles ovate to broadly triangular up to 2 mm long, acute.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals pale green, connate at the base for 0.3-0.5 mm, erect or slightly spreading, ovate to narrowly ovate, 1.5-2.1 by 0.6-1 mm, obtuse, puberulous or densely pubescent outside, glabrous or minutely pubescent around the apex inside, ciliate.
Stamens inserted at 5-5.8 mm from the base; anthers ovate or triangular, 0.8-0.9 by 0.3-0.5 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 25-35 cm by c. 1.5(-2) mm, glabrous.
Seeds brown, oblong, 5-6 by 1 mm, ends rounded, glabrous on both sides, longest cilia 13-17 mm long.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Borneo, Philippines (Palawan).

feature.char: Small or big tree 3-40(-50) m high, 5-100 cm dbh, buttresses usually absent or small up to 1 m high and spreading up to 2 m at the base.

Bark smooth or rough, minutely scaly, shallowly longitudinally fissured or both longitudinally and horizontally fissured, silver grey to dark brown; inner bark brittle, hard, creamy, yellowish brown with cream or orange streaks, whitish inside.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 2-11 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels (0-)1-4(-6) mm long, puberulous or glabrescent.
Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate, triangular, up to 1.5(-2) mm long, obtuse or acute, ciliate, glabrous or puberulous outside, glabrous inside.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals connate at the base for 0.5-0.8 mm, ovate or broadly ovate, sometimes turbinate, 1-2.5 by 0.8-1.8 mm, obtuse or rounded, sometimes mucronulate, ciliate, glabrous or puberulous outside, glabrous inside, erect or slightly spreading.
Stamens inserted at 2.5-3.8(-4.1) mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.8-1.5 by 0.3-0.6 mm, obtuse, sometimes acute or mucronulate.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 25-62 cm by 2-4(-4.5) mm, glabrous.

Seeds elliptic (sometimes slightly ovate), 5-10.5(-12) by 1.6-2.5 mm, pubescent on both sides, one end acuminate with an acumen 1-5 mm long (sometimes bifid at the apex), the other end rounded (rarely obtuse); longest cilia 5-10 mm long, becoming gradually shorter along the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Sri Lanka, India (Nicobar Islands), Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: throughout (except Java, Sulawesi, Nusa Tenggara).

Habitat & EcologyLowland to montane primary and secondary forests, on level lands, slopes or ridges, edge of mangrove, sometimes on flooded areas and heath forests, with the soil types sandy clay or loam, volcanic, or limestone. Altitude 0-2870 m.

UsesPowdered bark mixed with water is used as a traditional medicine, especially against skin diseases. It is also used to treat dysentery. The wood is hard and attractive and is very suitable for making furniture and flooring.
NoteAlstonia macrophylla is a widespread and very variable species. For discussion see Sidiyasa Blumea Suppl. 11 1998 149.

feature.char: Small to medium-sized tree 5-25 m high, 4-40 cm dbh.
Bark rough, shallowly longitudinally and horizontally fissured, grey or pale brown; inner bark yellow or yellowish brown, without exudate.
Branchlets glabrous or pubescent.
Inflorescence 4-9 mm long, many-flowered; pedicels 1-2.5 mm long, pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles scale- or sepal-like, ovate, 1-2 mm long.

Stamens inserted at 1.7-2.3 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.8-1 by 0.3-0.5 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 13-32 cm by 2.5-3 mm, glabrous.

feature.char: Small tree up to 8 m high.

Inflorescence 4-11 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels 1-3.5 mm long, pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate or narrowly ovate, up to 2.5 mm long, pubescent except at the base inside.
Flowers fragrant.

Stamens inserted at 2.3-3.2 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 1-1.2 by 0.3-0.4 mm, pointed.
Fruit 16-21(-24?) cm by c. 3 mm, glabrous, with narrow and acutish apex, blackish when dried.

Seeds narrowly elliptic, 5.5-7 by 1.5-1.7 mm, dark brown, pubescent on both sides, one end rounded, the other end acuminate, which is bifid at the apex up to 1 mm long; longest cilia 4-6 mm long, gradually becoming shorter towards the side margins.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Philippines.
Habitat & EcologySecondary growth in logged-over forests. Altitude 700-850 m.
NoteThe sterile material of A. parvifolia looks like that of A. angustifolia. For the distinction see SidiyasaBlumeaSuppl. 111998160 .

homotypes.specimenType: WhitmoreFRI 20548(holo L; iso K, KEP)Peninsular Malaysia, Pinang Island, Penang Hill, Moniots Rd.

feature.char: Tree 17-32 m high, 35 cm dbh.
Bark smooth, grey or pale brown.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescences 5.5-12 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels 1.5-4 mm long, pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate to broadly ovate, up to 1 mm long (the bracteoles are usually much smaller), obtuse to acuminate, ciliate, pubescent outside, glabrous inside.
Flowers with a slightly sour odour.
Sepals connate at the base for 0.8-1 mm, ovate, 1.7-2.5 by 0.8-1.5 mm, acute or obtuse, pubescent outside and on the free parts inside.
Stamens inserted at 3.5 mm from the base; anthers ovate, c. 1 by 0.35 mm, obtuse or mucronulate.
Fruit (known only from the type specimen) a pair of follicles, 60 cm by 3.5 mm, glabrous.

Seeds dark brown, narrowly ovate or elliptic, 8.5 by 1.8-2 mm, pubescent, one end acute or acuminate, acumen 1-1.5 mm long, the other end obtuse or rounded; longest cilia 10-12 mm long, gradually becoming shorter towards the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia (Penang).
Habitat & EcologyPrimary or disturbed forests, on hillsides. Altitude 200-600 m.
IUCN conservation categoryVulnerable due to acute restriction in area (VU D2).
NoteFor discussion and species distinction see SidiyasaBlumeaSuppl. 111998162 .

taxon.taxontitle: Alstonia pneumatophora Backer ex Den Berger

homotypes.specimenType: Endert28E.iP.505 (lecto L, designated by Sidiyasa (1998) op. cit.; iso BO, U)S Sumatra, Banjoeasin (= Banyuasin) , .
Endert28E.iP.537 (holo L; iso BO, U)South Sumatra, Palembang, Bayung Lincir, Banyuasin , .

feature.char: Tree 25-55 m high, 30-100(-200) cm dbh, fluted at base or forming tall and steep buttresses up to 8 m high, spreading for up to 3 m at the base.
Bark smooth or sparsely scaly, grey; inner bark pale yellow or orange-brown, soft, granular, with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 3-9 cm long, composed of two bunches of densely clustered flowers; pedicels 0-1 mm long, puberulous or densely pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles ovate or triangular, sepal-like, up to 2(-3) mm long, ciliate, pubescent outside, laxly puberulous around the apex inside, glabrous at the base, acute or obtuse.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals connate at the base for 0.2-0.4(-0.6) mm, ovate, 1.5-2(-3.5) by 0.5-1.2 mm, obtuse, pubescent outside, laxly puberulous around the apex and glabrous at the base inside, ciliate, erect, very often spreading when dried.
Stamens inserted at 5.2-8.4 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.7-0.9 by 0.3-0.4 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 10-20(-40) cm by 1.5-2 mm, shortly pubescent or tomentose, with a blunt or narrowly acute apex.
Seeds oblong, 4-4.9 by 1-1.2 mm, ends rounded, glabrous on both sides, longest cilia 8-12 mm long, reduced and becoming shorter (sometimes glabrous) toward the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Sulawesi.
Habitat & EcologySwamps or on periodically inundated areas along streams, on sandy loam or heavy loam soils. Altitude 0-50 m.
UsesThe wood is soft and suitable for carving. The wood of the aerial roots make a substitute for cork. The latex can be applied to wounds.

homotypes.specimenType: C.E. Parkinson6563 (holo K) Burma, Thanton, Yatheytaung.
Wallich1607(lecto NY, designated by Monachina (1949) op. cit.; iso C, E, G, K-W, L, M, NY, P, W)Burma, Martabania .
N.K. Chun & C.L. Tso44317(holo IBSC; iso A, K, P, US)China, Hainan, Mocheung Ling, Ting-on.

gathering.collectionAndType: (holo KEP; iso A, K, L, SAN)

feature.char: Tree 8-35 m high, 15-80 cm dbh, sometimes slightly fluted at the base, without buttresses.
Bark shallowly and/or irregularly fissured, pale or yellowish brown; inner bark yellow-orange, light brown or straw-coloured, granular, with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 2-5 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels (0.5-)1-2 mm long, glabrous or puberulous.
Bracts and bracteoles scale- or sepal-like, ovate or subtriangular, up to 1 mm long, curving or not, obtuse or acute, glabrous on both sides, not ciliate, leafy bracts sometimes present.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals dark green or pink, sometimes red, connate at the base for 0.2-0.4 mm, ovate or suborbicular, 0.9-1.2(-1.7) by 0.9-1.2(-1.5) mm, erect, rounded, glabrous outside, glabrous or laxly puberulous around the apex inside, ciliate.
Stamens inserted at 3-3.3 mm from the base; anthers ovate or subtriangular, 1-1.2 by 0.35-0.5 mm, obtuse or acute.

Fruit solitary, composed of a united pair of follicles, 16-30 cm by 8-12 mm, slightly laterally compressed and with distinct and narrow grooves on both sides on the flattened parts, glabrous, roughly striate and thick-walled.

Seeds elliptic or oblong, 9-11 by 2.8-3 mm, glabrous and a tuberculous on both sides (except surrounding the hilum, which is smooth), ends rounded; margin slightly thickened, longest cilia 10-17 mm long.

feature.string: Distribution China (Yunnan, Hainan), Burma, Thailand; in Malesia: Sumatra (known only from North Province and West Province), Peninsular Malaysia.
Habitat & EcologySecondary and primary forests, open places or hillsides. Altitude 367-1800 m.

gathering.collectionAndType: (holo M; iso K)
gathering.locality: Papua New Guinea, Central District, Port Moresby Subdistrict, near Boridi.

feature.char: Tree 12-25 m high.
Bark dark brown; inner bark light brown, without white latex from the trunk.
Branchlets glabrescent.
Inflorescence 3.5-5 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels stout 1-2(-3) mm long, softly pubescent.

Bracts and bracteoles sepal- or scale-like, ovate or triangular, 1-1.5 mm long, acute or acuminate, ciliate, densely pubescent outside, glabrous inside, the linear bracts (17-25 by 1-1.5 mm) and leafy bracts (c. 4.5 by 1 cm) sometimes present at the base of the inflorescence.
Flowers fragrant.
Sepals connate at the base for 0.8-1 mm, ovate, 2.4-2.8 by 1.6-2 mm, obtuse, ciliate, densely pubescent outside, glabrous inside, erect.
Stamens inserted at 3.6-3.7 mm from the base; anthers ovate 1.2-1.4 by 0.4-0.6 mm, obtuse or mucronulate.
Fruit a pair of follicles, c. 43 cm by 4.7-5 mm, glabrous.

Seeds dull-brown, elliptic or ovate, 6-8.5 by 2.6-3 mm, pubescent on both sides, one end acuminate with an acumen 1.5-3 mm long, the other end rounded; longest cilia 3-5 mm long, becoming gradually shorter towards the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Papua New Guinea.
Habitat & EcologyPrimary and secondary forests, in forests dominated by Ficus and Euphorbia. Altitude 1370-1420 m.
IUCN conservation categoryVulnerable due to fragmented and declining area (VU B1+2c).
NoteAlstonia rubiginosa is very similar to A. beatricis and A. parvifolia, for comparison see SidiyasaBlumeaSuppl. 111998171 .

feature.char: Medium-sized to big tree 10-50(-60) m high, 20-80(-130) cm dbh, fluted at the base or forming tall and steep buttresses up to 10 m high, spreading for up to 4 m at the base.
Bark smooth, scaly or shallowly fissured and peeling off in rectangular flakes, fawn or light brown; inner bark granular, creamy, yellow or straw-coloured, with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 4-13(-17) cm long, many-flowered, mostly formed of two dense bunches of flowers; pedicels 0-2 mm long, pubescent.
Bracts and bracteoles scale- or sepal-like, ovate or narrowly ovate, acuminate or sometimes trilobed or irregularly lobed at the apex, 1-3 mm long, ciliate.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals pale green, connate at the base for 0.3-0.7(-1) mm, ovate, 1.5-2.4 by 0.8-1.9 mm, obtuse, sometimes acute or mucronulate, pubescent outside, minutely pubescent or less often glabrous inside, erect, ciliate.
Stamens inserted at 5.2-8.4 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.9-1.2 by 0.4-0.5 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 20-40(-63) cm by c. 2(-2.5) mm, glabrous.

Seeds dark brown, oblong, 4.5-5.5(-7) by 1.2-1.6(-2) mm, glabrous on both sides, ends rounded; margin slightly thickened, longest cilia 8-12(-14) mm long, becoming much shorter or glabrous towards the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Pakistan, Nepal, Bhutan, India, Sri Lanka, Bangladesh, China, Burma, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos Vietnam, Australia, Solomon Islands; in Malesia: throughout.

Habitat & EcologySecondary and primary forests, savannahs, along streams (rarely in swamps), in coastal plains, on ridges or montane, on clay or ultrabasic soils, granite bedrock and limestone. Altitude 0-1230 m.

UsesThis species is the most important source of the pulai timber. This timber is used for household items and the pulp makes a high quality paper. As it is so light it can be used for fishing net floats. It can be used for the treatment of diarrhoea and stomach ache, snake bites, and for treating Herpes zoster by applying the latex on the affected parts. The tree is also sometimes used as an ornamental.

homotypes.specimenType: Blumes.n.(holo L [898.129-143]), W Java, near Rompin (= Rumpin).

gathering.collectionAndType: (holo K-W)
gathering.locality: , India, Punjab, Sermore (= Sirmur). The locality is incorrect according to Hooker (1882) and King & Gamble (1907).

feature.char: Tree 10-25 m high, 15-40 cm dbh, sometimes forming plank symmetrical buttresses up to 1.20 m high (bottle-shaped at the base known in New Guinea).
Bark smooth, scaly or finely fissured and peeling off in square or rectangular flakes, pale to dark grey or almost black; inner bark white, creamy or pale yellow, with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous.
Inflorescence 3-11 cm long, few (3-6)-flowered on each cluster; pedicels (2.5-)4-9 mm long, glabrous.
Bracts and bracteoles sepal-like, ovate or triangular, up to 1(-1.7) mm long, acute, ciliate or not.
Flowers fragrant.
Sepals connate at the base for 0.2-0.4 mm, ovate, sometimes broadly ovate or subtriangular, (1.2-)1.5-2 by 1-1.6(-2) mm, erect, obtuse or rounded, ciliate, glabrous on both sides.
Stamens inserted at 5-6.5 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 1-1.4 by 0.4-0.5 mm, obtuse.
Fruit a pair of follicles, 12-25 cm by 2.5-3 mm, glabrous.

Seeds oblong, 5-6 by 1.6-2.2 mm, ends obtuse or rounded, glabrous with very minute reticulate structure on both surfaces, thickened margin distinct on the hilar side, longest cilia (12-)15-22 mm long, becoming shorter (rarely glabrous) at the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Burma, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Java, New Guinea.
Habitat & EcologySwamps, mostly in secondary vegetation, on sandy soils. Altitude 0-600 m.
UsesThe wood can be used for household items, carving and plywood. The root wood is light and can be used as a substitute for cork. The latex is used in medicine for sores and skin ailments.

Blume1006 (lecto L, designated by Monachina (1998) op. cit.; iso L, 2 sheets)Java, Kuripan.

feature.char: Small or big tree (sometimes shrub) 3-30 m high, up to 90 cm dbh, sometimes with small buttresses.
Bark smooth, scaly or longitudinally fissured, corky, grey, brownish or dark brown; inner bark yellowish or straw-coloured, hard, granular, without white latex.
Branchlets glabrous or puberulous.
Inflorescences 2.5-11 cm long, many-flowered; pedicels 1-3 mm long, puberulous or tomentose.
Bracts and bracteoles scale-like, up to 1(-1.5) mm long, ovate or broadly ovate, acute or acuminate, ciliate, puberulous or pubescent outside, glabrous inside.
Flowers fragrant.

Sepals connate at the base for 0.3-1.2 mm, ovate, sometimes obovate or suborbicular, 1.1-3 by 1-1.8 mm, apex obtuse or rounded, sometimes mucronulate, erect, ciliate, pubescent outside, glabrous inside (less often laxly puberulous around the apex).
Stamens inserted at 1.6-3.4 mm from the base; anthers ovate, 0.9-1.2 by 0.3-0.5 mm, acute, obtuse or sometimes mucronulate with a pointed tip.
Fruit a pair of follicles, (15-)20-50 cm by (2.5-)3-4 mm, glabrous.

Seeds elliptic or narrowly so, sometimes ovate, 5-9 by 1.5-2.7 mm, dark brown, mostly blackish at the margin, pubescent on both sides, one end acuminate with an acumen up to 2.7 mm long (sometimes acute or cuneate), other end rounded or obtuse; longest cilia 6-13 mm long, becoming gradually shorter towards the margins.

feature.string: Distribution Northern parts of Australia and the Solomon Islands; in Malesia: Philippines, Java, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, the southern part of the Moluccas, New Guinea incl. New Britain.
Habitat & EcologyPrimary and secondary forests, coastal forests, on alluvial, clay, limestone or lateritic soils. Once reported in swamp forest. Altitude 5-800 m.
UsesThe wood is hard and can be used for construction work and household items.
NoteFor notes on this species see SidiyasaBlumeaSuppl. 111998184 .

taxon.figure: Fig. 1. Alstonia actinophylla (A. Cunn.) K. Schum. a. Leaf; b. open flower; c. follicles (a, b: Pullen7196; c: L.S. Smith11951 ).
Fig. 2. Alstonia angustifolia Wall. ex A.DC. a. Leaf; b. open flower; c. sepals, outside surface; d. sepals, inside surface (Anta614 ).
Fig. 3. Alstonia angustiloba Miq. a. Habit; b. pair of follicles; c. surface of follicle in detail (a: Elsener201; b, c: Bojeng Sitam8981).

Fig. 4. Alstonia beatricis Sidiy. a. Habit; b. flower in bud; c. pistil surrounded by annular disk-like thickening (corolla and calyx removed); d. corolla lobe from inside; e. corolla tube, dissected slightly stretched to show 3 anthers inserted in the glabrous zone (Van Royen5535 ).

Fig. 5. Alstonia breviloba Sidiy. a. Habit; b. flower in bud; c. dissected corolla tube, showing 3 anthers; d. corolla lobe; e. pistil, showing an annular disk-like thickening at the base; f. follicles; g. seed (a-e: Hartley TGH11952; f, g: Coode & Lelean NGF29940).

Fig. 6. Alstonia iwahigensis Elmer. a. Habit; b. flower in bud; c. dissected corolla tube, showing 3 anthers inserted above the hairy belt; d. corolla lobe; e. anthers, front view; f. anthers, side view; g. pistil, showing numerous ovules from the dissected ovary, annular disk-like thickening at the base, and a robust cleft apical part of the stigma (Ambriansyah & ArifinAA 898 ).

Fig. 7. Alstonia macrophylla Wall. ex G. Don. a, b. Leaves; c. detailed leaf beneath; d. flower in bud; e. dissected corolla tube; f. corolla lobe; g. pistil, showing an annular disk-like thickening at the base; h. follicles; i. seed (a, d-g: Ramos1895; b: Tandon3567; c, h, i: Tandon3257).
Fig. 8. Alstonia penangiana Sidiy. a. Habit; b. cluster of flowers; c. flower in bud; d. corolla lobe (WhitmoreFRI 20458 ).
Fig. 9. Alstonia rostrata C.E.C. Fisch. a. Habit; b. flower in bud; c. follicle (a, b: Sirirugsa457; c: Poilane2085).

Fig. 10. Alstonia rubiginosa Sidiy. a. Habit; b. leaf beneath in detail; c. flower in bud, also showing one bracteole on the pedicel; d. dissected follicle tube; e. corolla lobe; f. pistil; g. follicles (a-f: Foreman & Vinas LAE60288; g: Veldkamp & Stevens5921).

Fig. 11. Alstonia scholaris (L.) R.Br. a. Leaf; with an intrapetiolar stipule at base of petiole; b. flower in bud; c. dissected corolla tube, showing 3 anthers; d. corolla lobe; e. anthers, front view; f. anthers, side view; g. pistil, showing the pubescent ovary; h. pistil head, supported by the style and showing a cleft stigmoid apex; i. seed (a: Maxwell75-1083 ; b-i: Henty & SayerNGF.20588 ).
Fig. 12. Alstonia spatulata Blume. a. Habit; b. flower; c. fruit; d. seed (a, c, d: Niyomdham1920; b: Kerr15078).

Fig. 13. Alstonia spectabilis R.Br. a-d. Leaves; e. flower in bud; f. fopen flower; g. surface of sepals, outside; h. surface of sepals, inside (a: Kenneally7138; b: Hartley14735; c, e-h: Schodde & Craven4519; d: Kenneally10893).

feature.char: Climbers, scramblers or shrubs.
Branches sometimes with large corky protuberances.
Leaves opposite or in whorls of 3-7, more or less equal in size within a whorl but often of extremely different sizes and shapes on different parts of the plant; colleters present in the axils.

Inflorescences axillary and/or terminal, consisting of solitary flowers, of simple pleiochasia, or of compound pleiochasia and then sometimes forming large terminal panicles; flowers 5-merous (but see Alyxia kabaenae).
Sepals ovate to linear; colleters absent.
Disk absent.
Ovules several.
Seeds simple; endosperm ruminate (or with longitudinal ridges outside Malesia).
Embryo with flat to strongly undulate cotyledons.

feature.string: Distribution 106 species found from North-East India through Southern China to Taiwan and southwards through Southeast Asia to Australia and eastwards through the Solomon Islands out into the Pacific west as far as Henderson Island and north to Hawaii. In Malesia there are 55 species. This is by far the largest genus of Apocynaceae s.s. in Malesia. Map 3.

NoteMore detailed notes for many of the species in this large genus can be seen in Middleton Blumea 45 2000 1-146 . Some species of Alyxia from outwith Malesia have been observed to have leaves that are remarkably different in shape between the older and younger growth. Although this has not been observed to the same extent in Malesian species many are known from relatively few collections and may well be present.

key.keynotes: A single key to all the species in Malesia was published by Middleton (2000). As the genus is large and the previous key very long and complex only regional keys are given here. For some very widespread and variable species, such as Alyxia reinwardtii, the keys may reflect only the degree of variation for the species in the region to which the key pertains.

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF PENINSULAR MALAYSIA, SUMATRA AND BORNEO

question.text: Corolla tube > 4 mm long
Corolla tube < 4 mm long
Corolla tube densely to sparsely pubescent all over outside
Corolla tube glabrous to very sparsely puberulent (then not all over) outside
Bracts < 1 mm long; leaves mostly oval in shape with equally rounded base and apex; secondary veins obscure above
Bracts > 1 mm long; leaves variable in shape but not as above; secondary veins usually visible above, rarely obscure
Leaves mostly thickly coriaceous with strongly inrolled margins and venation obscure beneath; corollas fairly fleshy
Leaves papery to coriaceous, margins flat or weakly inrolled; corollas not fleshy
Leaves ovate to elliptic, if narrowly so then not pubescent beneath; inflorescence usually glabrous, rarely pubescent; fruit articles 13-28.2 mm long, fruit stalks 3.4-15 mm long

Leaves mostly narrowly elliptic or linear, rarely to ovate, usually sparsely puberulent beneath, sometimes only on the midrib; inflorescence puberulent; fruit articles 7.5-10.2 mm long, fruit stalks 1.8-2.1 mm long
Inflorescence 2.5-9 cm long, usually densely pubescent, rarely to glabrous; fruit articles 17-30 cm long. — Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia
Inflorescence 1-3.5 cm long, only very rarely densely pubescent; fruit articles 6-20(-25.3) mm long. — Widespread in W Malesia
Corolla bud head 0.35-0.49 of bud length; corolla lobes 1.1-1.2 mm long. — Not in Peninsular Malaysia
Corolla bud head 0.18-0.32(-0.42) of bud length; corolla lobes 1.2-3.8 mm long. — Peninsular Malaysia

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF JAVA AND THE LESSER SUNDA ISLANDS

question.text: Inflorescence mostly unbranched; flowers pedicellate; fruits ellipsoid
Inflorescence sometimes branched; flowers sessile; fruit (sub)globose

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF SULAWESI

question.text: Flowers solitary; leaves to 1.7 cm long
Flowers 3-15 in an inflorescence; leaves to 15 cm long
Calyx fused into a 2-lipped tube
Calyx of free sepals or only irregularly fused and then not in a 2-lipped tube
Inflorescence puberulent, delicate, peduncle 1-1.3 mm wide; corolla tube 2.8-3 mm long, 1.1-1.6 times as long as lobes, c. 1.5 times as long as sepals; fruit articles 24.5-27 by 14-16 mm
Inflorescence glabrous, robust, peduncle c. 1.8 mm wide; corolla tube 7-7.5 mm long, 2.1-2.7 times as long as lobes, c. 3.2 times as long as sepals; fruit articles 10.4-11.2 by 7.5-8 mm
Corolla tube > 4 mm long
Corolla tube < 4 mm long
Leaves in whorls of 6, blade thickly coriaceous; sepal apex obtuse
Leaves in whorls of 3 or 4, blade coriaceous or subcoriaceous; sepal apex acute or acuminate
Leaves pubescent beneath, at least on midrib; corolla pubescent outside
Leaves glabrous beneath; corolla glabrous outside
Corolla lobes 4.5-4.8 mm long, 4.5-4.6 times as long as wide
Corolla lobes 2.1-2.4 mm long, 1.4-1.9 times as long as wide
Inflorescence simple and unbranched with 5 or fewer flowers
Inflorescence branched or with more than one whorl of flowers, 6 or more flowers altogether
Branchlets glabrous; leaf blade 1.8-4.7 cm wide; inflorescence glabrous
Branchlets puberulent; leaf blade 0.3-1 cm wide; inflorescence puberulent
Leaves in whorls of 3 or 4; inflorescence with 6-8 flowers
Leaves in whorls of 5; inflorescence with > 10 flowers

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF THE MOLUCCAS

question.text: Erect shrubs or small trees; leaf apex mucronate; corolla lobes 3.5-5.9 mm long
Climbers; leaf apex not mucronate; corolla lobes 1.6-2.6 mm long
Pedicels with short stiff bracts; corolla tube 8.5-11.2 mm long
Pedicels lacking bracteoles or bracteoles only on pedicel of terminal flower; corolla tube 3-4.9 mm long
Inflorescence sparsely to densely puberulent; corolla tube > 4 mm long; corolla lobes > 2 mm long; ovary densely pubescent all over
Inflorescence glabrous; corolla tube < 4 mm long; corolla lobes < 2 mm long; ovary glabrous or pubescent only in a tuft between the carpels
Leaves in whorls of 3 or 4, blades 1-7 cm long; ovary glabrous
Leaves in whorls of 5, blades 4.5-13.1 cm long; ovary pubescent in a tuft between the carpels

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF NEW GUINEA

question.text: Leaf apex clearly mucronate; shrubs
Leaf apex not clearly mucronate; shrubs or climbers
All leaves opposite
At least some leaves in whorls of 3 or more
Secondary veins numerous, close together and barely distinguishable from tertiary venation, > 80 pairs; leaf margin strongly undulate; sepal apices rounded
Secondary veins variable, 18-58 pairs; leaf margin strongly undulate to flat; sepal apices obtuse to acute
Leaf margin strongly undulate; corolla tube c. 2.6 mm long; stamen insertion c. 0.35 of tube length; anther apex c. 1.4 mm from corolla mouth
Leaf margin not undulate to weakly undulate; corolla tube 8.5-11.2 mm long; stamen insertion 0.67-0.87 of tube length; anther apex 0-1 mm from corolla mouth
Leaves punctate beneath
Leaves not punctate beneath

Secondary veins 33-79 pairs, tertiary venation parallel to secondary veins and weakly prominent above; inflorescence with several clear internodes and unbranched side branches; corolla bud head c. 0.43 of bud length, apex acuminate
Secondary veins 14-23 pairs, tertiary venation obscure; flowers solitary or inflorescence a simple unbranched pleiochasium; corolla bud head 0.26-0.37 of bud length, apex obtuse to acute
Flowers solitary
Flowers in inflorescences
Inflorescence a simple unbranched pleiochasium or of axillary unbranched pleiochasia and a terminal compound pleiochasium with only 1 or 2 nodes
No inflorescences of simple unbranched pleiochasia, all compound
Corolla tube ≤ 3 mm long
Corolla tube > 3 mm long
Bracteoles present
Bracteoles absent or only on pedicel of terminal flower in an inflorescence
Branchlets glabrous; corolla tube glabrous outside; leaf short to long acuminate and rounded at the tip, leaves reaching 5.1-6.6 cm long
Branchlets densely puberulent, corolla tube sparsely puberulent around the top of the tube outside; leaf acuminate but notched at the apex, leaves reaching c. 2.4 cm long
Inflorescence robust; corolla tube > 8 mm long
Inflorescence not robust; corolla tube ≤ 8 mm long
Pedicels without bracteoles; corolla tube not continuously pubescent most of tube length inside. — Not on mainland New Guinea
Pedicels with bracteoles; corolla tube continuously pubescent except for base inside. — Mainland New Guinea
Bracteoles present
Bracteoles absent or only on pedicel of terminal flower in an inflorescence
Corolla tube 3.4-6 mm long, usually pubescent outside
Corolla tube c. 8 mm long, glabrous outside
Secondary veins not visible above
Secondary veins distinguishable above
Corolla tube 4.1-5 mm long; branchlets pubescent, sometimes glabrescent
Corolla tube 6.3-6.9 mm long; branchlets glabrous
Inflorescence frequently branched and forming large, lax terminal panicles formed from axillary and terminal inflorescences, often longer than the leaves
Inflorescence of various sorts of compound pleiochasia but not forming large lax panicles and generally shorter than the leaves
Pedicels with one bracteole immediately beneath the calyx; stamens inserted above the middle of the corolla tube
Pedicels with two bracteoles on the pedicel or without bracteoles; stamens inserted below the middle of the corolla tube (latter character not known in A. manusiana)
Corolla lobes elliptic, c. 0.9 mm wide; corolla tube 1.6 times as long as lobes; stamens inserted at 1.2 mm from corolla base which is 0.52 of tube length
Corolla lobes ovate or orbicular, c. 1.1 mm wide; corolla tube 2.5-2.7 times as long as lobes; stamens inserted at 2.2-2.3 mm from corolla base which is 0.65-0.7 of tube length
Leaf margin weakly inrolled; inflorescence 3.5-7 cm long; fruit articles 5.3-7.3 mm long
Leaf margin flat; inflorescence 4.3-16.5 cm long; fruit articles 5.5-19 mm long
Sepals 1.2-1.7 mm long; ovary pubescent around base only or pubescent in tuft between carpels; fruit articles 5.5-9.9 by 4.3-6.5 mm
Sepals 2.1-2.9 mm long; ovary densely pubescent all over; fruit articles 11.5-19 by 8.7-13 mm
Inflorescence exclusively terminal
Inflorescence not exclusively terminal
Leaf apex caudate; secondary veins 50-58 pairs; inflorescence c. 2 cm long, delicate; pedicels 4-5 mm long; corolla tube c. 2.6 mm long
Leaf apex emarginate to acuminate and then often notched at the apex; secondary veins 28-46 pairs; inflorescence 1.1-1.5 cm long, robust; pedicels 0-0.8 mm long; corolla tube 6.7-7.4 mm long
Secondary veins prominent, not particularly distinct from prominent tertiary venation so appearing densely packed, ≥ 100 pairs
Secondary veins variable, distinct or not, sometimes obscure, < 100 pairs
Inflorescence glabrous, 4-9 cm long
Inflorescence sparsely puberulent only in upper parts to densely puberulent, 1-2.5 cm long
Corolla lobes ≥ 4 mm long
Corolla lobes < 4 mm long
Corolla tube > 8 mm long
Corolla tube < 8 mm long
Corolla lobes ≥ 2 times as long as wide; flowers subsessile
Corolla lobes < 2 times as long as wide, or if more then clearly pedicellate
Bracteoles present on pedicels
Bracteoles absent or only on pedicel of terminal flower in an inflorescence
Only one bracteole immediately beneath the calyx
Bracteoles one on pedicel, two in various positions, or several
Branchlets sparsely to densely minutely puberulent
Branchlets glabrous
Corolla tube c. 2.1 mm long, 1.4-1.9 times as long as lobes
Corolla tube 2.8-3.3 mm long, 2.5-5.1 times as long as lobes
Inflorescence 1.1-3 cm long with 4-12 flowers
Inflorescence 4-9 cm long with 16-51 flowers
Corolla bud head acuminate, lobes 1.9-2.8 times as long as wide
Corolla bud head rounded to acute, lobes 0.9-1.6 times as long as wide
Corolla tube < 3 mm long; fruit articles > 25 mm long; inflorescence to 9 cm long
Corolla tube ≥ 3 mm long; fruit articles < 25 mm long; inflorescence to 3.5 cm long
Flowers 13-25 in an inflorescence which is very robust; corolla tube c. 3.4 mm long, c. 3.1 times as long as lobes; leaves reaching 10.1-18 cm long
Flowers 3-10 in an inflorescence which is not particularly robust; corolla tube 3.4-6.2 mm long, 1.6-2.9 times as long as lobes; leaves reaching 2.5-8.7 mm long
Corolla tube ≥ 6 mm long
Corolla tube < 6 mm long
Corolla glabrous outside; ovary pubescent in a tuft between the carpels; leaves spathulate, sometimes obovate
Corolla mostly pubescent outside, rarely glabrous; ovary densely pubescent all over; leaves never spathulate
Leaves in whorls of 3 or 4
Leaves in whorls of 5 or more
Corolla tube 1.8-3.8 mm long; leaf apex not folded back; 1.6-9.3 mm between fruit articles
Corolla tube 4.1-5 mm long; leaf apex often folded back; 0-1 mm between fruit articles
Corolla lobe apex acuminate; leaves strongly undulate at margin, apex long acuminate to caudate
Corolla lobe apex rounded to acute; leaf margin variable, apex variable but rarely long acuminate
Inflorescence with 25 or more flowers in an inflorescence
Inflorescence with 3-16 flowers in an inflorescence
Inflorescence glabrous
Inflorescence sparsely to densely puberulent
Ovaries pubescent in a tuft between the carpels or very sparsely pubescent only around the base; fruits with up to 7 articles in a chain
Ovaries pubescent all over or densely pubescent only around base; fruits with only up to 2 articles in a chain
Largest leaves on a plant at least 8.6 cm long
Leaves no longer than 8 cm long
Ovaries glabrous or pubescent only in a tuft between carpels; corolla lobes 0.7-1 mm wide
Ovaries densely pubescent all over to pubescent around base; corolla lobe 1.1-2.3 mm wide
Branchlets glabrous
Branchlets sparsely to densely puberulent
Bracts 0.9-1 mm long
Bracts 1.6-5 mm long
Corolla sparsely to densely pubescent outside; fruit articles 12.8-21.5 mm long
Corolla glabrous outside; fruit articles 9-10.5 mm long

key.keyTitle: KEY TO THE SPECIES OF THE PHILIPPINES

question.text: Leaves opposite
Leaves in whorls of 3 or more
Leaf blade ratio 10.7-20 times as long as wide, leaf blade linear, flowers solitary
Leaf blade ratio 1.6-8.8 times as long as wide, leaf blade not linear, if narrow then sides not parallel; flowers in cymes
Leaves pubescent above and beneath
Leaf pubescence variable but not pubesent all over above
Flowers solitary or an inflorescence of only 2 flowers
Flowers in cymes with 3 or more flowers
Bracteoles several along pedicel; pedicels 1-3 mm long; sepal apices obtuse, 2.3- 2.8 mm long, sparsely to densely puberulent
Bracteoles 2 immediately beneath calyx; pedicels c. 6 mm long; sepal apices acuminate, c. 1.8 mm long, sepals glabrous
Corolla tube < 4 mm long1 — Palawan
Corolla tube > 4 mm long. — Throughout the Philippines
Bracteoles present on the pedicels of all flowers. — Throughout the Philippines
Bracteoles absent or only on the pedicel of the terminal flower in an inflorescence. — Palawan
Many bracteoles on pedicels; inflorescence densely puberulent; 39-55 pairs of secondary veins
1 or 2 bracteoles on pedicels, very rarely more but then inflorescence at most sparsely pubescent and secondary veins < 39 pairs
Corolla lobe apex acuminate; leaves reaching 2.5-7 cm long, often notched at the apex even if acuminate; ovary pubescent all over
Corolla lobe apex rounded to acute, very rarely to acuminate but then leaves > 10 cm long, not notched; ovary glabrous, pubescent around base only or pubescent all over
Inflorescence with more than 1 whorl of flowers and clear internodes, not robust; fruit usually with several globose articles
Inflorescence with only 1 whorl of flowers at the end of the peduncle, rarely with more but then internodes short, inflorescence robust and fruit with 1 or 2 ellipsoid articles
Corolla tube continuously pubescent except for base inside; leaves to 20 cm long. — Not in Palawan or Sulu
Corolla glabrous or pubescent in upper half only inside; leaves < 10 cm long (in the Philippines). — Palawan, Sulu
Leaves thickly coriaceous, often somewhat fleshy, margin weakly to strongly inrolled; corolla slightly fleshy
Leaves papery to coriaceous, not fleshy, margin flat or weakly inrolled; corolla not fleshy

footnote.footnoteString: 1) Note that the small flowers occasionally found in the widespread and variable Alyxia reinwardtii and which would overlap with A. palawanensis in this couplet are found only in Peninsular Malaysia and are, therefore, not accounted for in the key to the species in the Philippines.

feature.char: Climber.
Branchlets weakly or strongly angled, sparsely lenticellate or not, glabrous or sparsely and minutely puberulent, glabrescent.
Sepals ovate, 0.8-2.7 by 0.6-1.3 mm, 1.1-2.1 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to acuminate, ciliate, glabrous to densely puberulent.

Fruit yellow, black, yellow-orange, orange, orange turning black, green to bright orange, finally dark purple, or orange-brown (most likely these recorded fruit colours all suggest an orangish or yellowish fruit which turns black or dark purple when mature), stalks 2.4-8.1 mm long, with 1-3 articles in each string, glabrous, articles dry smooth, fleshy or with thin flesh, 12.5-34 by 9.6-20 mm, ellipsoid or subglobose, symmetrical, apex rounded to acuminate.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Sulawesi (? see below). This species was incorrectly recorded as occurring in the Philippines by Middleton (2000) due to mistaken synonymy of A. obovatifolia under this species.
Habitat & EcologyIn forest, often disturbed, or kerengas on sandy, podsolic or poorly drained soils, sometimes ultramafic, at 5-1500 m.

NoteThis species is not always easy to distinguish from A. reinwardtii. In A. ganophylla the outside of the corolla always has hairs more than just dotted around the top of the tube and these hairs are usually extensive and much longer than those in the rare occasions when hairs occur on the tube in A. reinwardtii. In addition, the ovary is always densely hairy all over in A. ganophylla, again a character of rare occurrence in A. reinwardtii. The record from Sulawesi is not without doubt and better collections are needed to clarify this.

feature.char: Ground creepers or climbers.
Branchlets terete, weakly or strongly angled, densely lenticellate or not, glabrous to sparsely or densely puberulent.

Sepals free, not fleshy, linear, ovate or narrowly ovate, 1-3.5 by 0.4-1.8 mm, 1.2-3.8 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to acuminate, ciliate, glabrous or sparsely to densely puberulent all over or puberulent on tips only.

feature.string: Distribution Southern China, Burma, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Philippines (Palawan), Java, Bali.

Habitat & EcologyIn a wide range of habitats from primary or secondary lowland to montane or peat swamp forest or in scrub or open ridges. On granitic, sandy, clay or ultrabasic soils. Altitude to 3050 m.

NoteA discussion of the typification of this widespread species can be found in Middleton (2000). As this species is so variable it is not easily delimited from its nearest relatives A. angustifolia, A. ganophylla and A. pilosa, all of which can also be quite variable. Specimens with the smallest flowers are found in northern Peninsular Malaysia and southern Thailand. Even greater variability in A. reinwardtii is found in continental Southeast Asia.

feature.char: Climber.
Branchlets weakly angled, sparsely lenticellate, glabrous or sparsely and minutely puberulent, sometimes glabrescent.
Sepals ovate, 1.2-1.7 by 0.7-1.1 mm, 1.5-2 times as long as wide, apex rounded to acute, ciliate or not ciliate, glabrous or sparsely puberulent.

Fruit orange, maturing black, stalks 1.6-3.7 mm long, with 1-7 articles in a string, 1.5-3.6 mm between articles, glabrous, articles dry smooth or with thin flesh, 5.5-9.9 by 4.3-6.5 mm, ellipsoid or cylindrical, symmetrical, apex rounded or obtuse.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: New Guinea.
Habitat & EcologyIn closed or open primary or secondary forest or scrub at 1220-2100 m.

NoteThe inflorescence of this species is a large terminal panicle. It is composed of a terminal cyme with axillary cymes in the axils of normal to extremely reduced leaves. These leaves are often deciduous resulting in the appearance of a robust ‘peduncle’ with a whorl of cymes at the top. In the description the inflorescence length is taken from where these cymes radiate and the peduncle length is the length from here to the first branching in the inflorescence and does not include the length of this false peduncle. There is often a pair of opposite bracteoles in some specimens but not in others. These bracteoles may be interpreted as bracts with the flowers missing in some specimens.

homotypes.specimenType: Van RoyenNGF 20398(holo L; iso A, BRI, CANB, K, LAE)Papua New Guinea, Central Province, Mt Awormange, East of Woitape.

feature.char: Erect shrub, ground creeper or climber.

Sepals narrowly ovate, 2.5-2.6 by 1.5 mm, c. 1.7 times as long as wide, apex acute, ciliate, glabrous or sparsely puberulent outside.

Corolla tube cylindrical, c. 8 mm long, 3.2 times as long as sepals, 3.2 times as long as lobes, glabrous outside, sparsely pubescent around stamens and more densely in a band beneath them inside; lobes ovate, c. 2.5 by 2.1 mm, 1.2 times as long as wide, apex acute, base auriculate, glabrous outside and inside, not ciliate.

Fruit black or yellow turning black, stalks 1.7-3 mm long, with 1 or 2 articles in each string, 0.2 mm between articles, glabrous or sparsely puberulent at ends; articles with thin flesh, 7.8-12.5 by 5.6-9.5 mm, ellipsoid or sub globose, symmetrical, apex rounded or acuminate.
Seeds elliptic, c. 5 by 3.6 by 2.8 mm.

feature.char: Erect shrub or climber.

Seeds ovoid, 10.5-12.6 by 6.1 by 3.5-5.4 mm.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: New Guinea.
Habitat & EcologyIn forest at 400-1800 m.

NoteBracteoles are present on some pedicels but not on others. In the cases where there is a single bracteole the pedicel tends to be quite long so it is quite possible that the bracteole is actually a sterile bract. The secondary venation is not distinguishable from the parallel tertiary giving the impression of a very densely veined leaf like a Calophyllum leaf.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: New Guinea.

NoteThe material on which this species’ description is based is rather poor. This species is unusual in having the stamens inserted very low down in the corolla tube which also leads to an extremely short style. Unfortunately, due to the poor material, this finding is the result of the dissection of only one mature flower bud on the type specimen.

feature.char: Shrub-like when young with arching stems, climber when possible.
Stems densely lenticellate; glabrous to short puberulent.
Inflorescence lax, terminal and axillary, glabrous to sparsely puberulent, 4-20 cm long; pedicels 0.6-9.5 mm long.
Sepals 2-8 by 0.8-2.1 mm, 1.7-5.3 times as long as wide, puberulent to glabrous, oblong to narrowly ovate, apex acute or acuminate; with a continuous row of colleters on the inside.
Stamens inserted at 2.2-4 mm from corolla base which is 0.3-0.5 of corolla tube length; anthers 2.5-3.2 by 0.4-0.7 mm, 3.7-7 times as long as wide.
Disk of 5 wide rounded lobes to annular; 0.2-0.6 mm long, 0.3-1 times as long as ovary.
Ovaries 0.4-1.2 mm high, minutely puberulent to glabrous; style 1.5-3.1 mm long, style head 0.8-2 mm long.
Fruit linear, 16.5-74 cm by 4-10 mm, lenticellate, glabrous to sparsely puberulent.
Seeds 4.7-13.6 by 0.6-2.3 mm; coma 2-5.1 cm long.

feature.string: Distribution India, Bangladesh, China, Burma, Thailand, Laos, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Java, Philippines, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Moluccas.
Habitat & EcologyWide variety of habitats especially in drier evergreen and deciduous forest and as a scrambler in scrubland, to 850 m.

UsesA decoction of the roots is said to be used internally to treat urinary problems, as a tonic against fevers, as a treatment for anaemia and loss of appetite, and as an aid to menstruation. The leaves are also said to be edible with a sweetish taste. The fibrous bark can be used for binding.

feature.char: Climbers or scramblers; producing white latex.
Branches lenticellate or not; branchlets glabrous or, rarely, pubescent.
Inflorescence of axillary and/or terminal cymes, often forming panicles; flowers 5-merous, actinomorphic.
Sepal lobes free; colleters at sepal margins at the base inside.

Stamens included in the corolla tube, attached in a ring to the style head; anthers subsessile (except in the non-Malesian A. benthamianum), fertile in the upper half only, the lower half sterile, laterally with lignified guide rails and sagittate appendages at the base.
Disk annular, 5-dentate or 5-crenate.

Ovaries 0.5-0.7 mm long; style and style head 0.7-1.2 mm long.
Fruit unknown.

Stamens completely included within the corolla tube, attached at the insertion of the filament into the anthers in a ring to the style head; anthers with a short filament, fertile in the upper half only, the lower half sterile, laterally with lignified guide rails and sagittate appendages at the base.
Disk 5-dentate or 5-crenate, usually slightly shorter than ovary.
Gynoecium 2-carpellate, apocarpous but apically united into a common style, superior, ovoid, pubescent.

feature.char: Shrubs, small trees or lianas.
Branches bearing sharp spines, spines either simple or branched.
Leaves opposite, those of a pair equal, usually with few secondary veins; colleters in axils few or absent.
Inflorescence a terminal and/or axillary cyme, usually few-flowered; flowers 5-merous.
Sepals without colleters inside.
Corolla lobes dextrorse in bud (or sinistrorse in some African species); mature flower salverform with a narrow tube and spreading lobes.
Disk absent.
Gynoecium syncarpous, bilocular, each locule with 2 ovules; style filiform.
Fruit a fleshy berry; 4-seeded.
Seeds flattened, ellipsoid.

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 5 m tall, or a liana.
Branchlets glabrous to puberulent; spines simple or branched, sometimes slightly recurved.
Flowers fragrant.
Sepals ovate to narrowly ovate, 1.5-3 by 0.4-1.5 mm, 2.1-3.8 times as long as wide, apex acute to acuminate; glabrous, rarely sparsely puberulent, ciliate.
Ovary 0.5-1.5 mm long, glabrous or weakly papillose; style and style head 3-11.4 mm long.
Fruit ovoid or subglobose, 0.6-2.5 cm by 4-15 mm; glabrous.

feature.string: Distribution Arabia, Subsaharan Africa, Madagascar, Seychelles, Pakistan, India, Southern China and continental Southeast Asia, Australia, New Caledonia; in Malesia: Moluccas (Aru Islands), New Guinea, possibly also in Peninsular Malaysia.

NoteThis is an extremely widespread and variable species with a very large disjunction between the western and eastern parts of its distribution. It has not yet been collected in Peninsular Malaysia but has been collected in the far south of Thailand so may occur there. The specimens from New Guinea tend to have somewhat smaller flowers and shorter corolla lobes in relation to the corolla tube but these characters are also very variable over short distances in the western part of the range.

feature.char: Woody climbers, producing white latex.
Branches terete, lenticellate or not; branchlets terete, puberulent to glabrous.
Leaves opposite, those of a pair equal, petiolate; bases of petioles usually joined in an inconspicuous ring around the branch, with colleters in a ring on younger nodes.
Blade papery to coriaceous, entire, midrib impressed above and prominent beneath; secondary veins anastomosing before margin, tertiary venation scalariform and/or reticulate.
Sepals free, entire, often with a thick base, with a row of colleters at the base inside.
Disk of 2 separate ovate or oblong lobes alternating with the carpels.
Gynoecium 2-carpellate, apocarpous but apically united into a common style, glabrous, ovules many, style head fusiform with a sterile pointed apex.
Fruit of paired follicles, fusiform to terete, pointed at ends, somewhat laterally flattened, longitudinally dehiscent, many-seeded.
Seeds elliptic with a coma pointing towards fruit apex, grain slightly elongated at end with coma.

feature.string: Distribution 14 species in Southeast Asia and through Malesia to New Guinea. All species in Malesia. Map 5.
Notes1 Species delimitation in this account is quite different from the recent account by Leeuwenberg Syst. Geogr. Pl. 72 2002 127-166 and care should be exercised when comparing the two.
2 A seedling identified as Chilocarpus obtusifolius due to its close proximity to a mature adult had much narrower leaves than the adult. This may be true in other species too.

question.text: Leaf blade puberulent beneath
Leaf blade glabrous beneath
Inflorescence terminal and branched, 9.5-12 cm long; corolla densely pubescent all over outside except at very base

Corolla tube sparsely puberulent, at least in part, outside
Corolla tube glabrous outside
Branchlets densely pubescent when young, sometimes glabrescent when older; corolla tube sparsely pubescent only in lower half outside
Branchlets glabrous, even when young; corolla tube sparsely and minutely papillate-pubescent all over or pubescent only in upper half
Inflorescence mostly longer than subtending leaves; secondary veins on leaves weakly to not visible beneath
Inflorescence shorter than subtending leaves; secondary veins on leaves strongly prominent beneath
Branchlets minutely puberulent (use a lens!)
Branchlets glabrous
Pedicels without numerous bracteoles; corolla tube 6.8-8.2 mm long
Pedicels with numerous bracetoles; corolla tube 4.2-6 mm long
Inflorescence densely congested in leaf axils, shorter than subtending petiole
Inflorescence not densely congested, mostly longer than subtending petioles
Corolla tube < 6 mm long
Corolla tube ≥ 6 mm long
Pedicels with numerous bracteoles
Pedicels with 2 or fewer bracteoles
Leaves mostly with rounded or retuse apices; ultimate inflorescence nodes strongly congested so as to appear umbelliform; fruit globose
Leaves mostly acute to acuminate, more rarely to rounded; ultimate inflorescence branches not umbelliform; fruit various but not globose

Leaf blade coriaceous, base decurrent onto petiole; stamens inserted at 0.6-0.7 of length of tube from base; fruit long and torulose, constrictions between bulges around seeds mostly not less than half as wide as bulges around seeds

Leaf blade variable but mostly not coriaceous, base rounded to cuneate; stamens inserted at 0.3-0.6 of length of tube from base; fruit ellipsoid, fusiform or strongly moniliform with constrictions between bulges around seeds less than half as wide as bulges around seeds

Corolla tube 4-4.7 mm long; fruit strongly moniliform. — Borneo
Pedicels with many bracteoles; stamens inserted at around 0.5 of tube length from base
Pedicels with 2 bracteoles or fewer; stamens inserted at 0.2-0.4 of tube length from base
Inflorescence almost always longer than subtending leaves; secondary veins on leaves weakly to not visible beneath
Inflorescence only very rarely longer than subtending leaves; secondary veins on leaves prominent beneath

feature.string: Notes1 Leeuwenberg designated Blume s.n. (L 898.110-10) as the lectotype but labelled this specimen and another Blume specimen both as lectotype and did not state that the lectotypification was being done in his publication. Both specimens were equal candidates for lectotypification. I shall follow Leeuwenberg’s choice but under the ICBN the lectotypification is designated here.

2 Chilocarpus sunainaianus Yogan. and C. denudatus var. nicobaricus M. Gangop. & Chakr., both from the Nicobar Islands, have been synonymised under C. denudatus by Leeuwenberg (2002). I have not seen the types but this synonymy is likely correct.

3 It is extremely difficult to distinguish C. denudatus and C. torulosus in flower. The stamens tend to be inserted higher in the tube in C. torulosus but this conclusion is based on extremely inadequate mature flowering material of both species. Also the leaves of C. torulosus tend to be more coriaceous and it is confined to Borneo where C. denudatus is seemingly absent (but see note under C. conspicuus). They are easily distinguished in fruit. There is, however, the possibility that some of the immature flowering material from Sulawesi and the Moluccas, where no fruiting material of C. torulosus has been found, has been misidentified leading to a misinterpretation of the distributions of the two species. All the specimens from Borneo assigned to this species by Leeuwenberg are a mixture of other species of Chilocarpus, mainly C. beccarianus, and Andodendron. There is one old specimen of C. denudatus from a plant cultivated in Bogor that states that it came from Borneo but until wild material in fruit is collected there its presence in Borneo is not clarified.

Branchlets glabrous, not lenticellate.
Calyx ovate, 1.2-1.6 mm long, lobes 0.8-1.3 by 1-1.4 mm, 0.6-1.2 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to rounded, glabrous, ciliate.
Ovary 1-1.3 mm high, glabrous; style and style head 1.4-2.2 mm long.
Fruit ellipsoid, often warty, 5.5-8.2 by 3.1-4 by 3.2-3.5 cm, base cuneate, apex apiculate or acuminate.
Seeds 7-9 by 6-7 by 3.5-4.5 mm.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo.

string.habitat: In forest at low altitude.

feature.char: Large woody climbers.
Branchlets frequently lenticellate; bud scales or bud scale scars present at base of new growth.
Leaves opposite; colleters present in the axils.
Inflorescence a terminal panicle; flowers 5-merous.
Sepals often connate for large part of length; colleters in a row inside.
Fruit of paired follicles, mostly rather flattened, rarely fused together at the apices.
Seeds with a long narrowly acuminate end topped with a coma directed towards the fruit apex.

feature.string: Distribution About 10 species from India and China to Malesia; in Malesia 3 species.
NoteThis genus is in need of a comprehensive revision thoughout its range.

feature.char: Large woody climbers to 20 m high.
Branchlets sparsely to very densely pubescent or hispid, rarely glabrous; lenticellate.
Stamens inserted at 5.2-12.5 mm from corolla base which is 0.2-0.4 of tube length; anthers 7.2-13.2 by 1.2-2.2 mm, 4.3-8.8 times as long as wide.
Disk of a 5-crenate or 5-dentate ring, 0.6-1.5 mm high, shorter than the ovaries.
Fruit 17.6-40 by 1-2.3 cm, fusiform, flattened, glabrous to puberulent.
Seeds 13-35 by 4-7 mm with a beak 4-19 mm long; coma 26-70 mm long.

feature.string: Distribution India, Sri Lanka, Nepal, Bhutan, Bangladesh, Burma, Southern China, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo (one record from Brunei), Java, Philippines, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands (incl. East Timor).

string.habitat: In a wide variety of forest or scrub habitats, including on karst limestone.

feature.string: NoteChonemorpha fragrans is an extremely variable species with the specimens from Peninsular Malaysia seemingly particularly distinct with the longer calyx tube and correspondingly shorter lobes and the more densely pubescent calyx. In addition the corolla is generally somewhat smaller than usual. However, there are no discontinuities between these specimens and the rest of the material of the species which shows patterns of variation in other parts of its range.

feature.char: Woody climber.
Branchlets densely golden pubescent.

Corolla tube 12-23 mm long, 1.1-1.4 times as long as calyx, 0.8-1.4 times lobe length, glabrous or sparsely pubescent at top of tube outside, densely pubescent inside; lobes 12-38 by 6-14 mm, 2-2.7 times as long as wide, oblique obovate, glabrous outside and inside.
Stamens inserted at 5-5.5 mm from corolla base which is 0.3-0.5 of tube length; anthers 5-6.6 by 1.1-1.7 mm, 2.9-6 times as long as wide.
Disk a 5-crenate ring, 0.7-1.6 mm high.
Fruit unknown.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Java.
Habitat & Ecology Unknown.

NoteThis species is known from only a very few old specimens. It is very similar to C. fragrans but differs in the very small flowers and the densely pubescent inside to the calyx colleters. Further collections may show that it is merely an extreme variation of C. fragrans.

feature.char: Large woody climber.
Branchlets lenticellate, sparsely pubescent, turning glabrous with age.
Stamens inserted at 2.6-4 mm from corolla base which is 0.4-0.5 of tube length; anthers 3.3-4.3 by 0.6-0.7 mm, 4.9-5.7 times as long as wide.
Disk in a ring, crenate around the margin, 0.8-1 mm high, 0.3-1 times as high as ovaries.
Fruit of paired linear follicles, smooth, glabrous to sparsely puberulent, 15.8-44 cm by 6-17 mm.
Seeds: grain 11-30 by 3-4.8 mm of which rostrate apex 3.2-19 mm long, coma 2.7-7.5 cm long.

feature.string: Distribution India, Bhutan, China, Burma, Cambodia, Laos Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Java.
Habitat & EcologyIn a wide variety of forest or scrub habitats to 1000 m altitude.
UsesPreviously exploited for a high quality rubber before the widespread use of Hevea brasiliensis.
