feature.char: Shrub 0.5-5 m high.
Branches slightly lenticellate; branchlets glabrous.
Sepals ovate to subtriangular, very variable in size even within a single cyme, 2-5.5 by 0.8-1 mm, 2-7 times as long as wide, apex acute to acuminate, glabrous.
Disk cup-shaped, 0.8-1.4 by 0.6-1 mm, 0.4-0.6 times as long as the ovary, slightly crenate.

Fruit whitish purple when mature, usually of paired mericarps free from each other, with a very short stalk, sometimes only 1 carpel developing, ovoid, sometimes rather straight on one side and convex on the other side, 9-14 by 4.5-7 mm, 1.7-2.5 times as long as wide, apex acute to obtuse.
Seeds 1, obliquely ovoid, 7-11 by 4-5 mm, 1.7-2.5 times as long as wide, acute at both ends, glabrous.

feature.string: Distribution India, Sri Lanka, Burma, China, Thailand, Taiwan, Laos Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Java, Sulawesi, Lesser Sunda Islands, Philippines.
Habitat & EcologyIn open areas, lowland and montane rain forests. Also found in dipterocarp forests and bamboo-dominated forests. On clay, black soil or limestone rock from 30-2000 m altitude.
UsesThe root is used for hypertensive illnesses and as a sedative. Fresh leaves can be used externally to treat snake bites, wounds and eye problems.

feature.char: Large woody climbers, sometimes forming large shrubs with pendant branches be- fore beginning to climb.

Sepals pubescent; colleters inside.
Disk absent.
Fruit of 2 divergent follicles, connate at the base.

Corolla tube 13-32 mm long; anthers 13-25 mm long; leaves papery or coriaceous when dry, (5-)8-23 cm long

feature.char: Trailing shrub or climber to 12 m.
Branchlets densely lenticellate.
Sepals puberulent, ciliate, usually ovate, 3-19 by 1.5-6 mm, 1-6.5 times as long as wide, apex acute to acuminate.
Stamens inserted at 0.8-2.2 cm from corolla base; anthers 13-25 by 0.8-1.6 cm long of which acumen 10-19 mm.
Ovaries sparsely and minutely puberulent, 1.3-2.5 mm long; style and style head 10-18 mm long.
Fruit tapering into an obtuse apex, 10-30 by 1.9-4.8 cm, lenticellate.

feature.string: Distribution Burma, Thailand, Laos Cambodia, Vietnam, in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Java, Philippines, Sulawesi, New Guinea (Papua).

UsesTraditionally used as an ingredient of arrow poison. Also used locally as a heart stimulant.

feature.char: Slender climber reaching forest canopy, or trailing shrub.
Branchlets densely lenticellate, more rarely sparsely so.
Sepals 1.3-4 by 0.6-1.8 mm, 1.2-3.1 times as long as wide, ovate, apex acute, pubescent, ciliate.
Stamens inserted at 3.6-4.6 mm from corolla base; anthers 4.3-6.1 by 0.7-0.9 mm of which acumen 2.5-4 mm long.
Ovaries sparsely and minutely puberulent, 0.7-1.6 mm long; style and style head 4.1-5.1 mm.
Fruit 9.5-11.2 by 2.1-3.5 cm, densely lenticellate, fusiform, tapering towards apex.
Intact seeds not seen.

feature.char: Climber or trailing shrub.
Branchlets densely lenticellate.
Sepals glabrous or, rarely, slightly puberulent, ovate, 1.5-3.2 by 1.5-2.5 mm, 1.1-1.3 times as long as wide.
Stamens inserted at 3.2-6.5 mm from corolla base; anthers narrowly triangular, 4.3-4.8 mm long of which acumen 1.8-2 mm.
Ovaries 0.8-1.5 mm high, glabrous or minutely pubescent; style and style head 4-8 mm long.

feature.char: Climber or trailing shrub.
Branchlets densely lenticellate.
Sepals pubescent, ciliate, linear, 6-17.7 mm long.
Stamens inserted at 5-8 mm from corolla base; anthers narrowly triangular, 1-1.6 cm long of which acumen 7.5-12.5 mm.
Ovaries 1-2.3 mm, minutely pubescent; style and style head 6.5-10 mm long.
Fruit tapering to an obtuse apex, 11-24.5 by 2.5 cm, densely lenticellate.

nomenclaturalNotes.string: See Leeuwenberg (1991) for synonymy of non-Asian genera (but see note below).

feature.char: Shrubs or small trees; bark with copious white latex.
Branchlets glabrous or sparsely pubescent.
Sepals with or without colleters inside.
Disk absent.
Seeds covered in a fleshy aril.

feature.string: Distribution Approximately 100 species throughout the Old and New World tropics; in Malesia 13 species. Map 10.

Notes1 There remains some debate as to whether Tabernaemontana is monophyletic. In particular it is possible that the New World species of Tabernaemontana are more closely related to some of the genera that have not been synonymised into Tabernaemontana than they are to the Old World species of Tabernaemontana (Mary Endress, pers. com.). This may eventually lead to the genus being made larger to accommodate these other genera or to the splitting up of the genus into smaller monophyletic genera.

2 Species delimitation is rather difficult in Tabernaemontana and there has been some debate as to whether the broad species concepts adopted by Leeuwenberg (1991) should be followed. This is particularly true for T. pandacaqui which has an extremely extensive synonymy. The account here is largely adapted from Leeuwenberg (1991) rather than having been completely reworked. I have not listed all the synonyms for each species and the reader is referred back to Leeuwenberg.

question.text: Leaves in whorls or with occasional opposite pair
Leaves exclusively opposite
Corolla doubled
Corolla not doubled
Leaves subsessile, blade base subcordate
Leaves distinctly petiolate, blade base usually not subcordate
Inflorescence containing empty bracts; anthers sagittate at the base
Inflorescence without bracts or all bracts with flowers in the axils; anthers cordate at the base
Corolla tube 4.5-5.2 mm long; inflorescences very delicate; secondary veins 6-9 pairs
Corolla tube > 7 mm long; inflorescences variable but mostly not very delicate; secondary veins 4-26 pairs
Sepals not ciliate, 3-14 mm long, leafy and often cordate, or linear but always narrower at the base than in the middle
Sepals ciliate or not, 0.9-6 mm long, not leafy or cordate, widest at the base
Stamens inserted in lower half of corolla tube
Stamens inserted around middle or in upper half of corolla tube
Leaves papery; cultivated
Leaves coriaceous; native
Corolla tube ≥ 24 mm long
Corolla tube < 24 mm long
Sepals not ciliate. — Peninsular Malaysia
Sepals ciliate. — Throughout Malesia (except New Guinea)
Corolla puberulent on the lobes outside
Corolla glabrous on the lobes outside
Leaves thickly coriaceous; sepals 3-6 mm long
Leaves not coriaceous; sepals 0.9-4 mm long
Corolla lobes pubescent inside, at least in lower half, often also pubescent outside and at least ciliate
Corolla lobes glabrous inside or pubescent only at extreme base, mostly not ciliate
Inflorescence and flowers robust; cultivated
Inflorescence and flowers not robust; native
Head of bud in mature corolla bud acuminate or acute; sepals usually not ciliate
Head of bud in mature corolla bud rounded or obtuse; sepals ciliate or not
Corolla tube mostly glabrous inside, 3.7-11 times as long as sepals; fruit 2-40-seeded. — Throughout Malesia
Corolla tube pubescent inside, 8-12 times as long as sepals; fruit 1- or 2-seeded. — Peninsular Malaysia

homotypes.specimenType: Sibat ak LuangS.23639(holo L; iso A, BO, K, KEP, SAN, SAR, SING) Borneo, Sarawak, Mt Iju, Balingian.

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 5 m tall.
Bark grey, smooth; inner bark pale brown.
Sapwood pale brown.
Branchlets lenticellate, glabrous.
Inflorescence few-flowered, 3−15 cm long, delicate with a long thin peduncle to 6 cm long, glabrous, not densely lenticellate; pedicels 4−6 mm long.
Sepals ovate, 1−1.2 by 0.8−1 mm, 1.1-1.2 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous, ciliate, without colleters inside.
Stamens inserted in the upper 2/3 of corolla tube; anthers c. 1.2 by 0.4 mm.
Fruit of paired follicles, orange, obliquely obovoid, 15−32 by 8−18 mm, with or without ridges, 1- or 2- (or 3-)seeded.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Borneo.
Habitat & EcologyIn lowland mixed dipterocarp forest at altitudes to 250 m.
IUCN conservation categoryVulnerable due to fragmented and declining area (VU B1+2c).

NoteThe name implies, and the protologue states, that the flowers in this species only open at night. Given that specimens have been seen with both closed and open flowers and with no indication at what time of the day they were collected further study is needed to clarify whether this is true.

feature.char: Tree or shrub to 15 m tall, to 30 cm dbh.
Bark pale grey to dark brown, inner bark white to yellowish, wood white or yellowish.
Branches lenticellate, glabrous.
Sepals suborbicular or ovate, 1.5-3 by 1.2-3 mm, 1-1.5 times as long as wide, apex rounded to obtuse, glabrous, not ciliate.
Stamens inserted in the lower half of corolla tube; anthers 3.3-4.5 by 0.9-1.5 mm.
Fruit elongate and curved (often question mark-shaped) to subglobose, orange to orange-red, up to 20 by 10 cm wide but hugely variable in shape and size, with or without faint ridges, 10-20-seeded.

feature.string: Distribution Western Pacific Islands, Solomon Islands; in Malesia: Moluccas, New Guinea.

feature.char: Tree or shrub to 4.5 m tall, to 10 cm dbh.
Bark yellowish.
Branches lenticellate, glabrous.

Leaves opposite, subsessile; blade subcoriaceous, elliptic to oblong, 3-20 by 1-7 cm, 1.7-4.6 times as long as wide, apex short acuminate, base subcordate, glabrous above and beneath, often punctate beneath, 5-12 pairs of secondary veins, ascending.
Sepals 1.2-1.5 by 0.8-1 mm, c. 1.5 times as long as wide, apex rounded to obtuse, glabrous, not ciliate.
Stamens inserted slightly above the middle of the corolla tube; anthers 1.8-2 by 0.5-0.7 mm.
Fruit obliquely ellipsoid, possibly orange, 2-3 by 1-1.5 cm, with 4 ridges on each mericarp, 5-10-seeded.

Seeds with a red or orange aril.

Branches glabrous.

Seeds obliquely ellipsoid with longitudinal grooves, 7-10 by 4-6 mm.

feature.char: Shrub or tree to 30 m tall, to 50 cm dbh, with or without low buttresses.
Bark yellowish brown, brown, grey-brown or grey, finely fissured or with corky lenticels; inner bark pale cream.

Fruit of 2 follicles, separate or joined at base, orange, 8−16 by 5−16 cm, sometimes with faint ridges, many-seeded.
Seeds with a red aril.

nomenclaturalNotes.string: See Leeuwenberg (1991) op. cit. for further synonymy.

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 14 m tall.
Branchlets lenticellate, occasionally sparsely pubescent.
Flowers weakly or not scented.
Sepals ovate, 1−4 by 0.5−2 mm, 1-3 times as long as wide, apex rounded to acuminate, pubescent or glabrous, ciliate or not ciliate.
Stamens inserted in upper half of corolla tube; anthers 1.1-5 by 0.4-1 mm.
Ovary 1-2.8 mm long; style and style head 1.1-1.6 mm long.

Fruit of 2 separate follicles, orange, red or yellow, obliquely ellipsoid, 0.9-7.1 by 0.5-3 cm, apex acuminate, slightly reflexed, distinctly longitudinally ridged, glabrous or pubescent, 1-40-seeded.
Seeds with a red or orange aril.

feature.string: Distribution Southern China, Taiwan, Thailand, northern and eastern parts of Australia, and western Pacific; in Malesia: Java, Borneo (Sabah), Moluccas, Philippines, Lesser Sunda Islands, New Guinea.
Habitat & EcologyFound in a wide variety of habitats, particularly in drier areas.

Notes1 This is an extremely variable and widespread species that is in need of further research. P.I. Forster Austral. Syst. Bot. 5 1992 521-531 , has suggested that there are two widely sympatric taxa, T. pandacaqui and T. orientalis, which differ in floral morphology, leaf venation and habitat preference. Leeuwenberg (1988) op. cit., conversely, discussed why he was unable to separate the two taxa having examined specimens over a much wider range than P.I. Forster. The material is voluminous and an intensive future study should be undertaken. In the meantime I shall adopt Leeuwenberg’s concept.
2 The very extensive synonymy listed above is only for those names used in Malesia. Leeuwenberg (1991) op. cit. has listed many more synonyms from continental Asia, Australia and the Pacific Islands.

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 6 m high, to 10 cm dbh.
Bark pale grey to grey-brown, smooth; inner bark pale yellow.
Sapwood pale yellow.
Branchlets glabrous, with few lenticels.
Flowers fragrant.
Sepals ovate to oblong, 1.4-4 by 0.7−1.2 mm, 2-8 times as long as wide, apex acute or acuminate; not ciliate, glabrous to sparsely puberulent.
Stamens inserted in upper half of corolla tube; anthers 1.5-4 by 0.5-1 mm.
Ovaries 0.5-2 mm long; style and style head 5.3-16 mm long.
Fruit obliquely ellipsoid or oblong, longitudinally ridged, sometimes torulose, 2-6 by 0.7-2 cm, apex acuminate, 2-4-seeded.
Seeds obliquely ellipsoid, 8-10 by 5-6 mm.

feature.string: Distribution Burma, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Java.

string.habitat: Understorey shrub or small tree.

feature.string: NoteThe specific limit between T. pauciflora and T. rostrata is not entirely clear. Further research may reveal that specimens with long narrow calyx lobes, which have been assigned to T. pauciflora by Leeuwenberg (1991) and also in this work, might have to be transferred to a more broadly defined T. rostrata.

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 5 m high, to 3.5 cm dbh.
Branchlets glabrous.
Sepals ovate, 0.9-2 by 1-2 mm, 1-1.5 times as long as wide, apex usually obtuse, occasionally acute, glabrous, ciliate.
Stamens inserted in the upper half of the corolla tube with the anther apex just beneath the mouth; anthers 1.2-2.4 by 0.3-0.7 mm.
Ovaries 0.5-2 mm long; style and style head 7.2-19 mm long.
Fruit stipitate, often having a twisted appearance, 0.7-2.2 by 0.3-1.2 cm, apex caudate, usually strongly reflexed, 1- or 2-seeded.
Seeds obliquely ellipsoid with longitudinal grooves, 8-12 by 4-8 mm.

feature.string: Distribution Burma, Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam; in Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia.
Habitat & EcologyIn scrub or forest to 1700 m.

dichotoma
auct. non Roxb. ex Wall.: Leeuwenb.

feature.char: Tree to 21 m tall, to 60 cm dbh.
Bark brown or grey, fissured or scaly.
Sepals ovate, 2.8-3 by 1.6-2 mm, 1.4-1.9 times as long as wide, apex obtuse, more rarely rounded or acute, glabrous, not ciliate.
Stamens inserted in the lower half of the corolla tube; anthers c. 3 by 0.4 mm.
Ovaries c. 2 mm high; style and style head c. 1.7 mm.
Fruit oblique ellipsoid, to 37 by 14 cm, apex acuminate to obtuse.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia.
Habitat & EcologyIn primary or secondary forest or on mossy ridges to 1500 m altitude.

NoteLeeuwenberg (1991) synonymised T. polyneura from Peninsular Malaysia under T. dichotoma from Sri Lanka and included a number of specimens from northern Burma in the species. The status of the poor material from Burma is obscure. However, the material from Sri Lanka and Malaysia is appreciably different in the secondary venation, which is highly visible and sunken above in T. dichotoma and obscure or faint in T. polyneura. Also the Malaysian material tends to have acuminate leaf apices rather than rounded ones, the fruit is narrower and the sepals obtuse to acute rather than rounded. The flowers of the Sri Lankan material are more robust.

gathering.collectionAndType: (holo L; iso A, S n.v., US)
gathering.locality: Papua New Guinea, Rossel Island, Mt Rossel.

feature.char: Shrub or tree to 10 m tall, to 40 cm dbh.
Bark pale brown, inner bark orange.
Sepals ovate to oblong, 3.1-5 by 2.3-4 mm, 1.1-2.2 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous, not ciliate.
Ovaries 2.7-4 mm long; style and style head 3-3.5 mm long.
Fruit yellow or pale orange, ellipsoid, 4.2-7 by 0.8-2 by 0.8-2 cm, with prominent lateral ridges, apex acuminate.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sulawesi, Papua New Guinea (Rossel Island).
Habitat & EcologyOn a variety of soil types, including ultrabasic, in scrub or disturbed forest at 400-700 m altitude.
IUCN conservation categoryVulnerable due to fragmented and declining area (VU B1+2c).

NoteThis species shows a very unusual distribution, separated between Sulawesi and Rossel Island off SE Papua New Guinea. Further collections may lead to a reassessment of this species and a further examination of its relationship with T. sphaerocarpa, particularly in Sulawesi. It should be noted, however, that a similar but even wider disjunction occurs in the better known Carruthersia pilosa and that one cannot assume that better collections will necessarily lead to the species being dismantled.

feature.char: Shrub to 2 m tall.
Branches sparsely lenticellate; glabrous.

Sepals often leafy, often quite variable in size even within a single flower, mostly narrower at the base than at the middle, 3-14 by 1.3-4 mm, 2-7.7 times as long as wide, apex obtuse or rounded, not ciliate.
Stamens inserted around the middle or upper half of corolla tube; anthers 2-3 by 0.5-0.8 mm.
Ovaries 1 mm long; style and style head 5-12.5 mm long.
Fruit shortly stipitate, 3.8-5 by 0.8-2.3 cm, apex acuminate, sometimes torulose, several-seeded.
Seeds ovoid, 7 by 4.5 mm.

feature.string: Distribution India (Andaman and Nicobar Islands), Burma, Thailand, Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo, Philippines.

feature.char: Tree to 20 m high, to 40 cm dbh.
Bark smooth or shallowly fissured, dark brown, lenticellate.
Sepals ovate to suborbicular, 2-4 by 2-4 mm, 0.8-1.5 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous, ciliate.
Stamens inserted in the lower half of the corolla tube; anthers 2.5-3.5 by 0.6-1.2 mm.
Ovaries 2-3 mm high; style and style head 3-8 mm long.
Fruit obliquely ellipsoid to subglobose, 40-55 by 35-45 cm, apex mostly rounded, rarely to acuminate.
Seeds 10-12 by 5-6 by 4-5 mm.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Java, Sulawesi, Moluccas, Lesser Sunda Islands.
Habitat & EcologyForest or scrub to 1200 m altitude.

treatment.taxon:
Tabernaemontana ternifolia D.J. Middleton
Tabernaemontana ternifolia D.J. Middleton
Harvard Pap. Bot. 9 2005 387
RidsdaleSMHI 215 (holo L; iso PNH)Philippines, Palawan, Puerto Princesa municipality, Mt Beaufort, west spur, 815 m altitude.
Shrub c. 2 m tall, with copious white latex. Leaves in whorls of 3, with occasional opposite pairs on the same plant; petiole 7-11 mm long, glabrous; blade 5.5-13.2 by 1.7-4 cm, 2-3.6 times as long as wide, elliptic, apex obtuse to shortly acuminate with a blunt tip, base cuneate, glabrous above and beneath, 10-16 pairs of secondary veins, at c. 90° from midrib, mostly fairly obscure, tertiary venation obscure.
Inflorescence (immature) glabrous, few-flowered. Sepals ovate, apex rounded, glabrous, ciliate, with a wide row of colleters inside at base. Corolla (immature) white, fragrant, bud head rounded and minutely papillose pubescent, tube minutely pubescent in upper half inside. Stamens inserted in lower part of corolla tube. Fruit unknown.
Distribution Malesia: Philippines (Palawan).
Habitat & EcologyFound in stunted montane rain forest and open disturbed areas at 815-1500 m altitude.
NoteThis species is only known with immature flowers. It is probably related to T. macrocarpa but is instantly distinguishable on the leaf arrangement. Further collecting might lead to a reassessment of its relationships.
. Map 10. Distribution of Tabernaemontana taxa in Malesia. Numbers for each region refer to total number of taxa / number of endemic taxa. The number of taxa includes species and infraspecific taxa Fig. 96. Tabernaemontana corymbosa Roxb. ex Wall. Habit. Fig. 97. Tabernaemontana macrocarpa Jack.a. Habit; b. fruit. Fig. 98. Tabernaemontana peduncularis Wall. a. Habit; b. flower; c. dissected flower; d. fruit (a-c: Charoenphol3578; d: KyotoT-35963 ).

feature.char: Woody climbers.
Sepals with a row of colleters inside.
Corolla in bud a narrow tube, bulging around the anthers, and an ovate head, lobes dextrorse, salverform when open; lobes falcate, obovate or oblong.

Stamens subsessile, inserted below or above middle of tube, adnate at middle of anther to apex of style head and again at base of anther to base of style head; anthers fertile in the upper half only, the lower half sterile, laterally with lignified guide rails and sagittate appendages at the base.
Disk of 5 separate lobes; glabrous.
Fruit of paired follicles; fusiform or linear.
Seeds consisting of a linear seed and apical coma directed towards apex of fruit; glabrous.

feature.string: Distribution 6-10 species from India and Japan to western Malesia; in Malesia 3 species.

Notes1 There are considerably more names published in this genus than recognisable species but the patterns of variation have not been adequately studied. Most of these names pertain to taxa in Japan and China. The synonyms given for the taxa below are not intended to be exhaustive and I have included only those for which I have had ready access to the type material and could confirm their status. A more thorough synonymy must await a comprehensive revision of the genus.
2 Recent research has confirmed that the North American Trachelospermum difforme is not closely related to the Asian taxa and should be treated in the genus Thrysanthella.

NoteMerrill listed a number of collections for this species, most of which were lost when PHN was destroyed, leaving only a few duplicates in other herbaria. It has not been recollected since the species was published. This mirrors the situation with T. inflatum which has also not been recollected in Malesia for more than a century.

feature.char: Climbers; producing latex.

feature.char: Climbers.
Branchlets lenticellate; glabrous.
Inflorescence terminal or axillary, cymose, shorter than subtending leaves.
Flowers 5-merous, actinomorphic.
Sepals with colleters in the axils.

Stamens slightly exserted from the corolla tube, attached in a ring to the style head; anthers subsessile, fertile in the upper half only, the lower half sterile, laterally with lignified guide rails and sagittate appendages at the base.
Disk cup-shaped, shorter than the ovary, 5-lobed.

feature.string: Distribution 1 species in Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo.

feature.char: Branches lenticellate; glabrous.
Sepals ovate, 1-1.5 by 0.5-0.75 mm, 2 times as long as wide, apex acute, sometimes puberulent at apex, otherwise glabrous.
Stamens inserted at 2.1-3 mm from corolla base; anthers 2.5-2.6 by 0.3-0.5 mm, 5.2-8.3 times as long as wide.
Disk 0.4-0.5 mm long.
Ovaries 0.7-1 mm long; style and style head 3-4 mm long.
Fruit 30-60 cm by 1.5-2.2 mm.

feature.char: Trailing or climbing shrubs.
Branches lenticellate; branchlets glabrous or sparsely pubescent.
Inflorescence an axillary cyme, all axes pubescent; flowers 5-merous.
Disk 5-lobed; surrounding ovary to about the same length.
Fruit a follicle, sometimes formed from only one of the carpels; not lenticellate.

feature.string: Distribution 3 species from the Indian subcontinent to Southern China; in Malesia 1 species.

feature.char: Sepals ovate or narrowly elliptic, 3-7 by 1.5-2.5 mm, apex acuminate, reflexed or spreading.
Disk pubescent on top.
Ovaries densely pubescent, 1-2 mm long; style and style head 6-9 mm long, densely pubescent.
Fruit of somewhat flattened follicles, 15.5-16 by 2.3-2.5 cm.
Seeds not seen.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sumatra, Java to Lesser Sunda Islands (Flores). Widely cultivated elsewhere. There is one collection, Teijsmann 11802, from Pangkadjene on Celebes but it cannot be ascertained from the specimen whether this was a cultivated plant or not.
Habitat & EcologyIn forest to 600 m.

nomenclaturalNotes.string: See Leeuwenberg (1985) for further generic synonyms based on African material.

feature.char: Leaves opposite; petiole bases joining to form short ocrea, these sometimes obscure especially in older leaves.
Corolla lobes sinistrorse; mature corolla with narrow or trumpet-shaped tube and spreading lobes.
Disk adnate to sides of carpels.
Fruit of paired follicles, usually somewhat united at least at base.
Seeds covered in a fleshy aril.

feature.string: Distribution The genus has 12 species of which 7 are in Africa and 5 in Malesia. One of the Malesian species also occurs in Australia (Queensland).

NoteThis account is partly adapted from Leeuwenberg (1985) rather than completely reworked because I agree with the species delimitation he used. It has been updated to include new collections made since 1985.

question.text: Leaves densely pubescent beneath; corolla lobes ≥ 2 times as long as wide. — Borneo
Leaves mostly glabrous beneath, rarely puberulent but then corolla lobes < 2 times as long as wide. — Throughout Malesia
Sepals almost free or at least with lobes much longer than tube. — Philippines
Sepals connate into a tubular calyx with lobes much shorter than tube. — Throughout Malesia
Calyx tube closely clasping the corolla tube, 3.5-7.7 times as long as wide; corolla lobes apex obtuse to acute. — Philippines
Calyx tube not closely clasping the corolla tube, 1-3.3 times as long as wide; corolla lobes apex rounded to emarginate. — Throughout Malesia
Corolla tube 28-45 mm long; calyx 14-40 mm long
Corolla tube 9-24 mm long; calyx 10-20 mm long

feature.char: Branches lenticellate; branchlets glabrous.
Flowers with an unpleasant smell.
Stamens inserted near the base of the corolla tube, at 7-10 mm from base; anthers 7-8 by 2-3 mm.
Disk annular, c. 0.5 mm high.
Ovaries glabrous, c. 2 mm high, style and style head c. 10 mm long.
Fruit fleshy, free from each other, subglobose, 6−11 cm diameter.
Seeds with an orange aril, furrowed, 10-12 by 5-7 by 4-6.5 mm.

Flowers with a pleasant smell.
Stamens inserted at 17-40 mm from corolla base; anthers 4-8 by 1.5-3 mm.
Disk annular, c. 1 mm high.
Ovaries 2-3 mm high, glabrous; style and style head 15-36 mm long.
Fruit globose, rarely fusiform, 2.7-7 by 1.3-3.5 cm, brownish to reddish.
Seeds with an orange aril, furrowed, almost round and flattened and concave on one side or crescent-shaped where the concave side has folded completely over, 7.5-12 by 4.5-10 by 3.5-4 mm.

Branches lenticellate, glabrous even when young.
Flowers poor or pleasant smelling.
Stamens inserted high in the corolla tube; anthers 3-6 by 1.2-2.5 mm.

Fruit of free to united carpels (these may be present on a single tree) up to 12 by 15 by 10 cm, small when not fused, green to yellowish, with pale brown warts.

Bark pale green to whitish, lenticellate.
Branchlets pale grey-brown with a few large lenticels, glabrous.
Stamens inserted in the upper part of corolla tube, anther apex near corolla mouth; anthers 3.5 by 1.2-1.5 mm.
Disk annular, crenate, 0.4−0.8 mm high.
Ovaries 1−2 mm high, glabrous.
Fruit subglobose, 3.5−5 cm diameter.

Branches lenticellate; branchlets glabrous.

Calyx with lobes free to base or united for up to 12.5 mm, then usually very irregularly; lobes oblong to narrowly obovate, 22-33 by 3.5-5.5 mm, 4.2-6.3 times as long as wide, apex acuminate, glabrous.
Stamens inserted in the upper part of the corolla tube; anthers 5-8 by 2-2.5 mm.
Disk annular, c. 1 mm high.
Ovaries c. 2 mm high.
Fruit yellow-white, paired and subglobose, only known at c. 7 cm diameter.

feature.char: Woody climbers, producing white latex.
Branches lenticellate, glabrous or puberulent, bearing tendrils formed from modified inflorescences.
Flowers 5-merous, actinomorphic.
Stamen insertion variable, completely included within the tube, free from the style head; anthers ovate to narrowly ovate, apex acute or obtuse, base rounded.
Disk absent.
Fruit brown or yellowish, a fleshy berry, spherical, ellipsoid or pear-shaped, indehiscent; few- to many-seeded.
Seeds compressed ovoid, without a coma, smooth, with a very thin endosperm and thick horny cotyledons.

feature.string: Distribution 16 species in Indochina and western Malesia; in Malesia 15 species. Map 11.
Notes1 There is some question as to the assignment to species of sterile specimens with long narrow leaves, see Middleton (1993) op. cit.
2 Merrill wrote the names of several ‘new species’ on herbarium labels which he never actually published.

question.text: Corolla tube > 7 mm long
Corolla tube ≤ 7 mm long
Inflorescence brown pubescent; calyx lobes brown pubescent
Inflorescence glabrous or white puberulent; calyx lobes normally glabrous
Inflorescence axis longer than the subtending petiole; leaves dull ochre beneath when dry
Inflorescence axis shorter or as long as the subtending petiole; leaves not dull ochre beneath when dry
Leaves with 1 or 2 intercalcated veins parallel to the secondary veins; stamens inserted in middle of tube
Leaves with obscure or scalariform tertiary venation; stamens inserted below middle of tube
Corolla tube 28-30 mm long
Corolla tube 7.5-15 mm long
Leaves glaucous beneath; corolla tube > 9 mm long, lobes > 12 mm long
Leaves not glaucous beneath; corolla tube < 9 mm long, lobes < 12 mm long
Inflorescence brown puberulent
Inflorescence glabrous or sparsely white puberulent
Corolla tube ≤ 3 mm long. — Java
Corolla tube > 3 mm long. — Borneo
Inflorescence fasciculate and dense, peduncle shorter than subtending petiole
Inflorescence lax, peduncle longer than subtending petiole
Corolla tube inflated and much wider than head in bud
Corolla tube inflated only around anthers, not noticeably wider than head in bud
Leaves with distinct intercalcated veins between the secondary veins
Leaves with indistinct venation or with veins perpendicular to secondary veins and no intercalcated veins
Leaves thickly coriaceous, tertiary venation clearly visible perpendicular to and connected between secondary veins; calyx lobes < 1 times as long as wide
Leaves papery to coriaceous, tertiary venation faint or obscure; calyx lobes > 1 times as long as wide
Tertiary leaf venation largely obscure; leaves glaucous beneath; corolla lobes 3-3.7 mm long
Tertiary leaf venation clearly visible; leaves not glaucous beneath; corolla lobes 1.4-2.8 mm long
Secondary veins in leaf almost straight with 1-3 intercalcated veins between; leaves dull above and beneath
Secondary veins in leaf strongly ascending or, if not, then without intercalcated veins and leaves shiny above
18-30 flowers per inflorescence; leaves dull above, 1.4-2.8 times as long as wide
8-15 flowers per inflorescence; leaves shiny above, 2.3-3.8 times as long as wide

feature.char: Woody climber to 60 m.
Branchlets glabrous, very rarely minutely puberulent; lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 0.9-1.8 mm long, lobes 0.5-1 by 0.4-0.7 mm, 1-2.5 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to acuminate, glabrous, ciliate.
Fruit globose to ovoid, 1.9-14 by 1.9-14 cm, pale green, yellow, orange or reddish.

feature.string: Distribution India (Nicobar Islands), Southern Thailand; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Moluccas (Buru).
UsesProduces a poor quality rubber. The stems can be used for binding and the fruits are edible. The latex can also be used to treat ulcers.

NoteThis species is very variable in leaf shape, size and venation. It can readily be distinguished from the other species of Willughbeia by its combination of a small inflated corolla tube and short delicate inflorescence.

homotypes.specimenType: Wood, Smythies & P.S. AshtonSAN.17525(holo L; iso BO, BRI, BRUN, K, KEP, SING)Brunei, Kuala Belait, Andalau Forest Reserve.

feature.char: Woody climber to 20 m.
Branchlets glabrous or sparsely rufous pubescent; branches lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, thick, 1-1.4 mm long, lobes 0.5-0.7 by 0.3-1 mm, 0.6-2 times as long as wide, apex rounded, rufous pubescent, ciliate.
Corolla tube cylindrical, 10-14 mm long, c. 10 times as long as calyx, rufous puberulent in 5 rows down tube or glabrous, pubescent in throat; lobes 6-8.2 mm long, oblong or elliptic, ciliate or not.
Fruit spherical, 6.6-8 cm diameter.
Seeds c. 2.6 by 1.5 by 1.3 cm.

feature.char: Woody climber to 35 m.
Branchlets glabrous; densely lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1-2 mm long, lobes 0.6-1 by 0.9-1 mm, 0.7-1 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous, ciliate.
Corolla tube inflated, 1.8-2.8 mm long, glabrous outside and inside; lobes 2-2.8 mm long, ovate, apex obtuse, glabrous.
Fruit spherical, 3-11.2 by 2.2-9.5 cm, green, yellow or orange.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sumatra (identity uncertain), Borneo, Sulawesi.

NoteOnly one collection is known from Sumatra, in Aceh, and this collection is in fruit. It has been provisionally identified as W. beccariana but the discovery of flowering material may change this conclusion.

feature.char: Large climber to 30 m.
Branches mostly glabrous, very rarely puberulent; lenticellate.
Sepals oblong or ovate, 1.5-4 mm long, lobes 0.8-3.3 by 0.6-1.9 mm, 1.1-2.5 times as long as wide, apex rounded to acute, glabrous, ciliate.
Fruit spherical, pear-shaped, oblong or ellipsoid, 2.6-12 by 1.7-7 cm, green, yellow or orange.

feature.string: Distribution Southern Thailand; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore, Borneo, Java.
Habitat & EcologyClimber in primary or secondary forest to 1600 m.

UsesBefore the introduction of Hevea brasiliensis as the main source of rubber W. coriacea was cultivated in plantations to produce a high quality rubber. The latex and dried powdered fruit are used to treat ulcers and the bark is used to treat headaches and to stop bleeding. A decoction of the root is used against dysentery. The fruit is edible.

feature.char: Woody climber.
Branches glabrous, lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1.8-2.7 mm long, lobes 1.1-1.9 by 0.8-1.7 mm, 0.7-2 times as long as wide, apex rounded, rarely acute or obtuse, glabrous, ciliate.

Corolla tube cylindrical, 3.8-6.5 by 1.5-1.9 mm, 0.4-0.7 times as long as lobes, 1.6-2.4 times as long as calyx, outside glabrous, inside puberulent; lobes oblong, 4.5-15 by 1.3-2.5 mm, 3.5-6 times as long as wide, ciliate or not.
Fruit spherical or oval, 1.7-5.8 by 1.2-5.8 cm, yellow or orange.
Seeds 6-16 by 4-13 by 3-6 mm.

feature.string: Distribution India (incl. Nicobar Islands), Bangladesh, Burma, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos Vietnam; in Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore.
UsesPreviously exploited for a poor quality rubber before the widespread use of Hevea brasiliensis. The fruit is edible.
NoteMasamune (1942) reported this species from Borneo but I have seen no material from there.

Seeds oval 2.2 by 1.7 by 0.9 mm.

Branches glabrous, lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, very thick, 1.5-2 mm long, lobes 1-2 by 1.5-2 mm, 0.7-1 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous or weakly puberulent, weakly ciliate.
Fruit ovoid, 8-10 by 6-7 cm.
Seeds c. 5.5 by 4 cm.

feature.char: Large woody climber to 40 m.
Branchlets usually minutely and sparsely puberulent, more rarely glabrous; branches lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1.9-2.6 mm long, lobes 1.1-1.6 by 1.2-2 mm, 0.7-1.1 times as long as wide, apex rounded or obtuse, often undulate edged or slightly reflexed, puberulent, ciliate.
Immature fruits spherical.

feature.string: Distribution Southern Thailand; in Malesia: Peninsular Malaysia, Borneo.
UsesThe latex has been used for rubber but as the plant is not common it was never commercially exploited.

homotypes.specimenType: Blume881(holo L [898.112-435])Java, Gunung Seribu .

feature.char: Woody climber.
Branchlets glabrous; lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, apex rounded, 1-1.2 mm long, lobes 0.7-0.9 by 0.7-1.2 mm, 0.75-1 times as long as wide; glabrous, ciliate.
Corolla tube inflated, 1.3-3 mm long, glabrous outside and inside; lobes 1.2-2.7 mm long, ovate or elliptic, glabrous.
Fruit unknown.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Java.

NoteMarkgraf identified a number of sterile specimens with large leaves as youth forms of this species. However, there is no direct evidence of the relationship either on the specimens or in the literature so these specimens are not included in this description. Further fieldwork is needed to show the range of variation in leaf shape and venation although, as all the herbarium specimens of this species are 19th century, it may be difficult to find further examples. Only the type specimen gives location information beyond just Java.

feature.char: Woody climber to 20 m.

Sepals ovate, 1.2 mm long, lobes 0.7 by 0.8 mm, 0.87 times as long as wide, apex rounded, glabrous, ciliate.
Fruit spherical, 3-5.5 cm diam., green or white.
Seeds 2 by 1.3 by 1.1 cm.

Inflorescence of a short peduncled cyme with flowers clustered at ends, brown tomentose, 5.4-7 cm long; pedicels 1.3-3.5 mm long.
Sepals ovate, strongly imbricate, 1.1-1.5 by 1.8-2.1 mm, 0.6-0.7 times as long as wide, apex rounded, tomentose.

Fruit unknown.

Corolla tube cylindrical, c. 7.6 mm long, outside glabrous, inside puberulent; lobes partially ciliate.
Fruit oblong, c. 4.8 by 1.5 cm.
Seeds rounded, flattened, 9-12 by 7-10 by 2.5-5 mm.

Fruit unknown.

feature.char: Woody climber to 33 m.
Branchlets glabrous or sparsely brown pubescent; older glabrous, lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1.3-2.5 mm long, lobes 0.6-1.2 by 0.5-1 mm, 1-1.3 times as long as wide, apex rounded to acute, brown pubescent.
Fruit spherical to 4-17.6 by 4-12 cm.
Seeds c. 1.7 by 1.2 by 1.1 cm.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Borneo, Philippines (Palawan).

NoteThere have been a number of spelling variations of the specific epithet. I, along with others, have assumed that the basionym name was misspelled in the protologue, as it is clearly intended to reflect the collecting locality of Sarawak, and the accepted name reflects a correction of this mistake.

citation.refPart: J. Straits Branch Roy. Asiat. Soc.

feature.char: Woody climber.
Branchlets rufous pubescent to glabrous; branches lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1.2-1.8 mm long, lobes 1-1.6 by 0.8-1.6 mm, 1-1.9 times as long as wide, apex rounded to acute, rufous pubescent or, rarely, glabrous, ciliate.
Fruit pear-shaped, 6-15 by 4.5-11.5 cm.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Singapore.

UsesPreviously exploited for low quality rubber before the widespread use of Hevea brasiliensis. The fruit is edible. The latex has also been used for the treatment of scabies and other skin ailments.

feature.char: Shrubs or small trees.
Leaves opposite; usually with glands in the axils.
Inflorescence a terminal cyme; few- to many-flowered.
Sepals with 5 large or small colleters in the sinuses inside, the larger ones almost covering the inner surface of the sepals.
Disk absent.
Fruit of paired follicles or connate follicles; fusiform.
Seeds linear or narrowly fusiform; with a coma directed towards the base of the follicle.

feature.string: Distribution Approximately 25 species in Africa, Asia and Australia; in Malesia 8 species (one of which may not be native).

question.text: Corolla infundibuliform; stamens completely included in the corolla tube
Corolla rotate, salverform or somewhat infundibuliform; stamens clearly exserted from the corolla tube
Flowers pendulous; corona absent
Flowers pendulous or not; corona present
Corona with antipetalous lobes divided more than half way to base giving the whole corona a fimbriate look
Corona with antipetalous lobes entire or divided less than half way to base
Antipetalous corona lobes deeply divided or at least strongly dentate
Antipetalous corona lobes entire or at most weakly crenate
Gynoecium syncarpous; fruits solitary. — Philippines
Gynoecium apocarpous but united into a single style; fruits paired. — Widespread
Corolla tube 3.8-4 mm long; stamens inserted in the upper half of the corolla tube
Corolla tube 1.8-2.8 mm long; stamens inserted in the lower half or around the middle of the corolla tube
Corolla tube 3.7-10 mm long, 1.7-5.5 times as long as sepals. — Philippines
Corolla tube c. 3.5 mm long, c. 1.6-1.9 times as long as sepals. — New Britain

gathering.collectionAndType: (lecto P, designated by Middleton (2005) op. cit.; iso BM, CGE, K)

feature.char: Small trees.
Branchlets sparsely to densely puberulent.
Inflorescence 2.5-3.5 cm long, often with leafy bracts; peduncle 0.2-1.3 cm long, sparsely pubescent, pedicels 4-7.5 mm long, pubescent.
Sepals ovate, 1.1-4 by 1.8-4.5 mm, 0.3-1.1 times as long as wide, apex rounded, sparsely pubescent, ciliate, colleters large in sinuses.
Gynoecium of 2 adnate carpels, ovary 1.5-2.6 mm high; style and style head 5-7 mm long.
Fruit of a single follicle that splits lengthways at maturity as each of the 2 component follicles dehisces, 20.5-22 by 1.4-2.2 cm, glabrous.

feature.string: Distribution Malesia: Philippines.

string.habitat: Evergreen or mixed deciduous forests.

Branchlets glabrous or sparsely puberulent, becoming glabrous and lenticellate.

feature.char: Shrub or treelet to 4 m tall.
Branchlets glabrous, sparsely lenticellate with age.
Sepals ovate, 1-1.5 by 0.9-1.1 mm, 1.1-1.4 times as long as wide, apex acute to obtuse, glabrous, ciliate, colleters small in the sinuses.
Stamens subsessile, inserted at 0.3-0.5 of tube length from base, exserted from tube; anthers 2.6-5 by 0.4-1 mm, pubescent only at the top outside.
Gynoecium of 2 free carpels united into a common style, ovaries 0.7-1.1 mm high, glabrous; style and style head 1.8-4 mm long.
Fruit paired, linear, 6.6-18 cm by 2.5-4 mm, glabrous.
Seeds 10 by 0.6 mm; coma 21 mm long.

feature.char: Shrub or tree to 37 m tall and 106 cm dbh, buttresses present or absent.
Bark smooth to rough and flaky, grey, greyish brown or cream-brown; inner bark white, cream or pale brown.
Branchlets glabrous, sparsely lenticellate with age.
Sepals ovate, 0.7-2.5 by 0.8-2.3 mm, 0.9-1.2 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to rounded, glabrous to densely puberulent, ciliate; colleters wide and large.
Gynoecium of 2 free carpels united into a common style, ovaries 0.7-1.8 mm long, glabrous; style and style head 3.5-5.5 mm long.
Fruit of paired follicles; 10-50 cm by 5-17 mm, glabrous, lenticellate or not.

feature.char: Shrub or tree to 15 m tall, to 30 cm dbh, often deciduous; wood pale.
Branchlets sparsely pubescent to tomentose, becoming glabrous; sparsely lenticellate.
Sepals ovate, 1-4 by 1.2-2.7 mm, 0.8-1.9 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to acute, tomentose or puberulent, colleters large and wide in the sinuses.
Gynoecium of 2 adnate carpels, ovary 1.5-2.7 mm long, glabrous, carpels medially connate; style and style head 8-10.5 mm long.
Fruit of connate follicles, splitting into 2 at dehiscence, 9.3-38 by 0.9-2.2 cm, minutely puberulent or, rarely, glabrous, minutely lenticellate or not.

feature.string: Distribution China, Thailand, Cambodia, Laos Vietnam; in Malesia: Sumatra, Peninsular Malaysia, Western Java, Philippines, Sulawesi.

NoteWrightia pubescens subsp. lanitii and subsp. pubescens differ in the size and shape of the sepals and, for the most part, in the pubescence of the antipetalous corona lobes. However, there are individuals that have some pubescence on the inside of the corona lobes and specimens from Sulawesi have the corona type and sepal shape of subsp. pubescens but the sepal size of subsp. lanitii.

taxon.taxontitle: Wrightia religiosa (Teijsm. & Binn.) Benth. ex Kurz

feature.char: Shrub or small tree to 5 m tall.
Branchlets puberulent, soon becoming glabrous and sparsely lenticellate.
Sepals ovate or oblong, 1-2.5 by 0.7-1 mm, 1.9-2.4 times as long as wide, apex obtuse to acute, glabrous, ciliate; colleters small and narrow.
Gynoecium of 2 free carpels united into a common style, ovaries 0.8-1.1 mm high, glabrous, of 2 separate carpels; style and style head 5.7-8.3 mm long.

feature.string: Distribution Thailand, Cambodia; in Malesia: Possibly Peninsular Malaysia. The natural distribution of this species is now obscure because it is so widely cultivated but is probably Thailand and maybe Cambodia. It may also be native in Peninsular Malaysia but is certainly widely cultivated in many parts of Malesia.

feature.string: Possibly a Cleghornia.
This name was placed by Fernadez-Villar under Alyxia odorata and by Merrill under Alyxia spec. although in the absence of a type or an adequate description its status is not certain.
Described from material from the Moluccas. Within Apocynaceae it could only be Carissa spinarum but could also have been described in the wrong family.

gathering.locality: from the Philippines, Luzon, Rizal Province, Montalban.

feature.string: I have been unable to locate any type material of this species. The holotype was probably destroyed in PNH. From the description it appears to be distinct from C. pilosa but I have seen no other material which matches the description.
There are a number of Korthals collections of both Parameria laevigata and P. polyneura in the Leiden herbarium and it is not obvious which was intended to be the type.
The identity of this species, which Miquel (1837) suggests is found in the Moluccas, is uncertain.

homotypes.specimenType: Heynes.n.(untraced).

feature.string: Index Kewensis suggests this is a synonym of Aganosma marginata = Amphineurion marginatum. If this is the case then the epithet cristatum would have priority. Displacing the current name in the absence of a type would seem unwise.

homotypes.specimenType: Heynes.n.(untraced).

feature.string: Index Kewensis suggests it could be a Cryptolepis.
Possibly an Alstonia or Rauvolfia.
Index Kewensis suggests it may be a Wrightia.
Included in the Apocynaceae by Wight but is rather Loganiaceae.
Boerlage has suggested his specimen from Sumatra represents an unknown variety but no material has been found which would clarify this.

homotypes.specimenType: Ledermann11618(untraced).

feature.string: Markgraf compares his new species to Parsonsia wollastonii which is now a synonym of P. sanguinea. It may be that this species is also a synonym of P. sanguinea and may be synonymous with var. sepikensis but without the type material or any other material identified by Markgraf its determination cannot be guaranteed.

The genus has been synonymised in Holarrhena by De Kruif Meded. Landbouwhoogeschool Wageningen 81-2 1981 where he made the species a synonym of Holarrhena pubescens with a neotype from India. However, the protologue states that the corolla aestivation is sinistrorse, whereas it is dextrorse in Holarrhena. Also the plant was collected in Java and Holarrhena is unknown in Java. As the neotypification is in conflict with the protologue it can be abandoned and in the absense of any material its identity is a mystery.
Plumeria is not native in Asia and the identity of this species is unclear.

homotypes.specimenType: Van Romburgh62(untraced)Borneo, Kalimantan, Teloek.

feature.string: Probably a synonym of Urceola brachysepala.
Leeuwenberg Rev. Tabernaemontana 1 1991 128 lists T. subcapitata as a synonym of Tabernaemontana bufalina Lour., a species not known in Malesia. It is unclear what species Miquel intended.

The type specimen was not indicated in the original description but Miquel mentions a Reinwardt specimen from Sulawesi in his account: I have been unable to locate this specimen. The only other species known from Sulawesi is W. beccariana although W. angustifolia, found in Borneo and Buru, possibly also occurs there.

This taxon appears in a list of Willughbeia species in Pichon Mém. Mus. Natl. Hist. Nat. sér. 2 24 1948 153 . However, I have been unable to locate it in Blanco’s works and Merrill, Sp. Blancoana (1918) makes no mention of it. Pichon lists it as a species that has been published but that he has not seen. It could, therefore, be a typographical error for W. multilocularis Blanco which is a synonym of Ardisia squamulosa Presl.

gathering.collectionAndType: (lecto L [898.112-484], designated by Ngan, Ann. Missouri Bot. Gard. 52 (1965) 143; iso U (fragment))

feature.string: This species was described by Miquel in 1857 from a specimen from Timor. It is a synonym of Wrightia tinctoria, a species otherwise known only from India. Its appearance in Timor is a mystery and is likely to be either a mistake on the label or else a cultivated plant transported from India earlier. There are no notes on the label to indicate, or otherwise, that it was a cultivated plant. Until such time as further material is collected in Timor that matches this specimen and its status can reassessed I am not including this as a Malesian species.
